RATING: 6.2
Juego entretenido y barato, bonita presentación, buenos dibujos, coloridos y bonitos y una historia que engancha, es rapido de jugar, y con distintos niveles de dificulta, hay alguna variación por internet que alarga la vida del juego. 
Tiene un gran pero...
es cooperativo, y a no todo el mundo le gustan este tipos de juego, muchas veces para que un juego funcione tiene que tener competición, y este no la tiene.
Si te gusta hay que poner algunas normas como que a pesar de ser cooperativo nadie sea el lider, es decir siempre hay alguien que impone un poco más su forma de jugar, y al final es ese jugador el que realmente juega y el resto solo asiente y asiste a la partida.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I would say Forbidden Island is a better "gateway game" than Dominion or Pandemic, simply because it covers a lot of different aspects of gaming than just deck-building or worker placement. A person can apply theme to the game and really play up the suspense, or two or more players can see how well they can work together to get off the island. As a light and filling game, this one delivers. I'm always disappointed when a game ends in defeat, and I'm always overjoyed when a game ends in victory. Usually, at this point, we just barely win or lose - but the gameplay is almost like a dance, or like playing chess. Despite that familiarity, this game doesn't get old.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
[i]tl;dr - I've found Forbidden Island to be totally replaced by its younger brother, Forbidden Desert. Highly recommend you check that one out instead.[/i]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

Forbidden Island has you working together to get off of an island that's slowly sinking into the ocean. Players must work together to discover various artifacts and then race to the center to be airlifted away. 

I found this game unfun and not challenging enough. Players are contributing to their own demise by drawing the Waters Rise cards, so it adds a feeling of second-guessing and strategy that's very enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Feels like a simplified form of Pandemic. One big difference being that the mechanics in Pandemic make more sense (except for the fact that just 4 people are saving the entire world from 4 virulent diseases out-breaking all at once). Feels like you're mostly running around the island with buckets, trying to get all the water out of places that seem far enough from the island's coast that they have no business sinking before the coastal spaces.

RATING: 7
So I bought this for my mother - the reason being that is is a cooperative game, that can be played with only one person (she usually games alone) and it does not involve fighting of any kind (she doesn't like fighting or games that involve fighting.)  

So my hours of research to find a game she would like paid off.  She loves it.  She's already played it once alone, and we played it together once too.  It was a great game to play together.  I like cooperative games, and this is a comparatively easy cooperative game.  

The island sinks at a very fast rate - we barely won - if the waters rose anymore we all would have flooded.  But it was great seeing my sister save us all by taking us off the island in the helicopter, just before the place flooded.  It felt desperate up until the end.  A great game, and one I hope to play again when I visit my mom.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
The precursor to Pandemic.  Great game for complete newbies to board games.  Even better for younger players.  The main criticism is that it's too simple and not challenging enough for more experienced players.  It's not to say that you can't lose this (especially if you play the rules correctly and discard sunken islands).  It's more like there isn't any interesting choices to make and it's fairly obvious where you should go after a couple of plays.  Pros are by the cheap price compared to more sophisticated games and lots of great looking tiles.  Unfortunately, unless you have younger players you probably won't play this much after a few games.  If you have younger players then this is well worth it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

RATING: 6
I don't like co-op games in general, and I REALLY don't like Matt Leacock draw-some-cards-and-see-what-awful-but-still-boring-thing-happens games.  But I think Forbidden Island is his best game for what it is.  The components are beautiful to look at, the mechanics are simple, and it's over before I hate it too much.  For me, games like Pandemic and Forbidden Desert just muck up the purest version of what is already a flawed formula.  This is another one that I don't usually play but will bring out from time to time for non-gamers.

RATING: 5
I don't usually like cooperative games, but this one has an elegant little ruleset and plays quickly enough that I don't mind playing it occasionally. And the steady disappearance of the tiles really lends the game some concrete physical tension that I find absent in most other co-ops.

(cooperative; 2x)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is almost exactly like Pandemic but has fewer things going on and fewer loss conditions.  More focus on the things it does, though, which is actually kinda nice.

Great way to introduce gaming and hand management/prioritization to new or younger players, and I plan on keeping it to teach to the next generation when they come of appropriate age.

After revisiting, the game is significantly better when using alternate layouts (rather than a beefy plus, try a tower or a skull or an X), as they make decisions more meaningful.

The game works well at teaching players to identify and act upon priorities, and start to guess probabilities.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played this game just once, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

I see how this game might be just perfect for a family setting... and maybe I went into it hoping for something more interesting, but I wasn't really impressed by Forbidden Island. It has really cool components and art, the theme is neat and the game is very smooth and simple to play. Yet, having such a limited amount of options, the game is too straightforward and easy for me.

All you care about is 5 tiles in total out of 24, so you can afford to lose a lot of them... all you have to do is to stalemate the game by flipping the tiles that get hit by the water, while you search for the right cards... and it's pretty simple to do so, since - until the water hits 3 tiles per turn - you can easily flip (almost) all of them back. When you have the right cards, you can take the artifact at the cost of losing a few tiles, but they are still so many that I can hardly see how this could be a big deal. There's only two ways this game can beat you: bad luck placing the tiles at the beginning or bad luck drawing cards during the game... and I don't like this!

Forbidden Island may be good for family and young players, but I think I would rather choose other co-ops over this one for those settings. The game is not bad... just it didn't grab me and it disappointed me a little, considering how hyped up it used to be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
FAMILY

Pandemic light. A good first cooperative game. Assume the roles of adventurers who are trying to uncover four treasures before the Forbidden Island sinks into the abyss.

Recommended with 1-4 players (best 4). 30 mins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is a nice game, despite the fact that the tin is very difficult to put on my shelf. What an awkward shape! I think a description of Forbidden Island as Pandemic Lite is very accurate, but it certainly provides fun for all ages. It may appeal more to mores serious gamers when raising the water level to begin, however it's fun in general. Some land masses quickly become inconsequential if they aren't connected to something you need, but overall it's a fun, well constructed game. Not something I'd play every week, but something I certainly wouldn't complain to see on the table.

RATING: 6
The tiles look great.  Unfortunately, this is not a new really cool co-op.  It's a "kid's version of Pandemic" -- there are differences, but essentially they all amount to reducing the complexity of Pandemic.  It's much less a "gamer's game" than Pandemic, and probably at the point where 'rich decisions' are too few to hold interest for long.  Perhaps if the tiles were more differentiated that wouldn't be true (imagine if the Observatory let you, I don't know, look at the next few flood cards, so you wanted it not to sink for reasons other than mere math of the deck), but I'm not sure.  Buyer beware -- might be good for kids, and certainly playable, but it's not a "quick Pandemic."  It is a _kid's_ Pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pandemic's just plain better.

RATING: 6.9
My rating for Forbidden Island has just plummeted from 8.5 to 6.9! My opinions about the game have not changed at all: so why the major drop in my rating? Because I have just discovered the joys of Forbidden Desert. I think about the only times I would want to play Forbidden Island now would be those occasions when Forbidden Desert was not an option!

Two very similar games; but Forbidden Desert is the vastly superior of the two games! The only strong point which Island has over Desert is the spiffy disappearing island mechanic.

RATING: 6
I don't think it would be unfair to call this game Pandemic for Kids, as it's the same designer and the same core mechanics, but with everything simplified a bit and the theme changed to be more kid-friendly (I assume kids would rather be treasure hunters exploring island ruins than be the CDC trying to prevent biological Armageddon).

If kid-friendly was a priority for me, I'd probably rate this game more favorably, but I don't have kids, and I don't play with kids, so I'd rather just play Pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Almost the same mechanics as [thing=30549][/thing], but boring.  We played two games back to back and there was no stress and no challenge in defeating the game.

From my opinion the game itself is flawed from the fact that the "Waters Rise" card locations are not controlled in the Treasure deck.  If they do not come until late in the game it becomes very easy to have most of the treasures in hand before the first bad card shows up.

I doubt this will be played again.  Pandemic is a masterpiece, this is crap.  I'm almost thinking of giving this game a "broken" rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Forbidden Island is a co-op game, like Matt Leacock's earlier Pandemic.  And it recyles that clever mechanic of returning the discard pile to the top of the draw deck.  The theme of the sinking island and the ratcheting up of pressure towards the end are quite well done.  However, the game doesn't give the players a great deal to do beyond staying dry while waiting for sets of treasure cards to turn up.  The decisions in our games have been altogether too straightforward.

Artwork and production quality of Forbidden Island are both very good.  The rules are clearly written and unambiguous.

RATING: 8
Requires a decent amount of strategy. Giving each player a unique role is a nice subtle way to enforce cooperation and planning.

Good for families, as with it being a cooperative game you don't have to worry about letting younger players win or older players steamrolling.

Overall, it's a great game for casual and younger players who want a thrilling cooperative experience. Groups of purely older players might find the game to be a bit simple eventually, however there's a nice mechanic that allows you to set the appropriate difficulty. However, remember that difficulty does not really enhance depth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is probably one of the best introductory strategy boardgames out there. It is fully co-op so there's no dirty play. The theme is very interesting. The production values are dollar for dollar some of the best out there. And its quick and easy to learn.

That being said, there's not alot of in depth strategy involved. The best move is usually fairly obvious and repeated plays of this will likely feel stale after a while. For the price though, this is hard to beat.

___________________
\_______GER_______/
Mit der Familie Weihnachten 2012 gespielt (Mitspieler von 8 bis 85) sehr gutes Einsteigerspiel für Koop! Der Nichte (8) hat es sehr gut gefallen. Die Karten und die Figuren sind sehr hübsch und unterstützen die Spielatmosphäre.
Am Anfang auch noch auf Anfängerlevel überflutet worden. Dann hat sich aber doch sehr schnell ein Gefühl für das erfolgreiche Vorgehen eingestellt. Durch verschiedenen Insel Layouts und verschärften Startbedingung (höherer Startflutlevel) kann man das Spiel auch öfters spielen ohne das die Herausforderung fehlt. Ich bin mir sicher, das es sicherlich noch häufiger aus dem Regal kommt zum (Ein-)Spielen für ein Koop-Spiel und ganz sicher als Solospiel.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Still one of my favorite co-op games. Fairly quick to set-up and play. The only thing that can get annoying is flipping flooded tiles over, especially when there are pawns on them, only to flip them back over the next turn. We've modified our game to include tokens that you put on top of flooded tiles. Only downside to this is it's sometimes hard to get a full scope of the situation of the board as the underside of the tiles are easier to see than a token. It's really not that big of a deal, I'm just lazy. I wouldn't let any of what I've said deter me from recommending it to anyone, especially couples. This was the first board game I was able to get my wife to play as she's not a fan of one vs one games and it's normally just the two of us. It says 2-4 players but this can very easily be played solo if you're so inclined. Just make sure you play a couple characters or you'll find it very difficult to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

NEED STANDARD X 58

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
A tile-laying, tile-removing game, where players have variable powers to grab treasure, shore up sinking tiles, and escape the island to win the game.

The artwork is beautiful, the game extremely well-balanced, and just about every go is tense and exciting.

However, there's very few chances for strategy here -- it's pretty shallow in that regard.  And short.

Easy to teach, easy to learn, more of a children's game or gateway game; don't be expecting something deep.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
When cooperative games emerged, the trend was to develop advanced games for the gamers.  Game play increased as did complexity.  Then this game arrives on the scene.  Extremely approachable for gamers and non-gamers alike.  And able to be taught to younger players (my 4 y.o. likes this game!).  Add in game length appropriate to the game level and a fantastic price point and you get a winner.

RATING: 9
Great family game.

I enjoyed playing this game. I played with my partner and our 5yo daughter on the easiest difficulty.

It's testament to the kind of tension this game can create when my partner dropped an f-bomb after a waters-rise card in front of our daughter, haha, oops!

When my daughter was not busy calling her mother out on her use of language she was super-fixated on getting the treasure and she really got right in to the story. Make sure you read out the scene-setting text at the beginning of the rule book to get eveyone in the mood.

Awesome looking figurines by the way - my daughter loved the crystal fire treasure and wanted to take it to school for 'News Day' - haha.

Probably not a game kids can play by themselves without a few adults to keep them on track, but if you're comfortable explaining all the options - good and bad - to the little ones AND letting them make their own choices, everyone is going to have a good time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

The only reason why I knock one point down is that the gameplay can get a little bit samey, and that I miss the exploration aspect (something that Forbidden Desert successfully added in).

RATING: 7
a faster, friendlier Pandemic.

The game has a stronger tension than pandemic.  It stays true to it's cooperative roots and plays very well.

Suffers from the same micromanagement problem as Pandemic, though.

Most important point, though...the pieces are immaculate and the presentation is dead on.  I would recommend on glitz alone.  But the compelling game play from Pandemic is there and makes this game a solid purchase.  And a bargain to boot!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
While I already see Pandemic as a very good gateway game, I must admit its lighter brother is much more non-gamer friendly: the gorgeous components and easier gameplay are a big bonus in enticing new gamers. But there's more than just that: Forbidden Island has some more tension and emotion! While the game progresses and the Island disappears from under the player's pieces' feet, you can feel the pressure pump and the tension grow!

The german edition comes in a cardboard box (no tin, sadly), and has some not-over-the-top miniatures.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
This game is light, quick, easy, and gorgeous. It's a nice game to have in your collection, as anyone can understand the concept and the rules. Great to play with kids without being bored to tears as you may be with games specifically designed for them. It's small on your shelf, the art is fantastic, and it serves its purpose well; but don't buy this game expecting it to be a significant addition to your collection. You're not going to get hooked and play it every night for a month. It's good to have, but buy something else with it if you're looking for something compelling to sink your teeth into.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial Impression: I have to say that I was surprised after my first play of this game. The components are top-notch, with wonderfully illustrated tiles made of thick cardboard. I applaud the use of physical treasures to the game instead of cards or tokens. The gameplay is fairly simple to teach and easy to grasp. However, I was happily surprised at how quickly the game's tension and difficulty ramped up. The final rounds feel like a mad scramble to do everything that needs to be done. Luckily my daughter tells me that she enjoys the game so I suspect that we'll be getting this to the table fairly often. I'm hoping that this will serve as a gateway to more complex cooperative games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Seven plays in with 2, 3 and 4 players each played at least twice.

This is a decent gateway cooperative game, but when it's held in comparison to Pandemic, Ghost Stories or Defenders of the Realm, it just isn't very good.  In all of the games played, starting at different levels of difficulty, I've never had the feeling of foreboding, even when I've lost.  Furthermore, at the end of the game, win or lose, I just haven't cared.  If I'm playing any game, cooperative or not, I want to care whether I've won or lost.

I've reread the rules a couple of times to ensure I wasn't missing some major part of the game, but that doesn't seem to be the case.  I'll most likely give it a few more tries, use it as a gateway cooperative game for complete non-gamers, but not reach for it for any other reason.  Even then, I'll most likely hit up Pandemic 95% of the time for reasons listed above.  

Quite disappointing.  :soblue:

RATING: 7
Like New
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[i]Posted: 7/2/10, Rated: 7[/i]

"It's [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i] lite!"  Yes, and no.

At first blush, [person=378]Matt Leacock[/person] didn't have to look much further than his first cooperative title for mechanics.  Let's see: multiple roles with special powers, four somethings that must be discovered by turning in matching sets of cards, and an event deck whose revealed cards are recycled each time a negative card is found.  Yep, sounds like [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i] but without that whole disease mess.

However, there are significant differences that lend [i]Forbidden Island[/i] its own unique identity.  The first is a modular board constructed from 24 tiles which are placed randomly.  Think [i][thing=13642]Louis XIV[/thing][/i] without the spaces.  Instead of finding cures for diseases, players are looking for four ancient artifacts.  Each artifact can only be discovered on two [-]research stations[/-] temple tiles (two for each artifact; eight temples in total).  And instead of having cities rise in infection, the island is sinking beneath the water as you go.

And here is where [i]Forbidden Island[/i] really comes into its own.  You know that whole "three cubes and then outbreak" mechanic from [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i]?  If you don't, then go [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/Spiele/Pandemie/]try it online for free[/url] on [url=http://www.brettspielwelt.de/?nation=en]BSW[/url].  [i]Now[/i].  I'll wait.  In [i]Forbidden Island[/i], it's two strikes and then you're sunk.  If you don't "shore up" the flooding, then an island tile will be removed from play after only two appearances of its card in the event deck.  More importantly, its matching card is also removed.  This means that the event deck is [i]always[/i] going to do something bad to you; No "free actions" if you've found the cure to Black, and a black city is drawn.

This simple change makes a huge difference.  The island really feels like it's sinking.  There are also new conditions for losing the game: if both Temples for a particular artifact sink before you have retrieved that artifact, then you lose.  And if your escape tile "Fools Landing" ever sinks, then you lose.  It's a mad rush to the finish, as you try to keep avenues open for your characters to use.

The last thing I want to mention is the "box."  It is actually a tin, with a plastic insert inside that stores all of the components well.  The artwork on all of the cards, tiles, and the tin is fantastic.  [i]Forbidden Island[/i] may sound like [i][thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing][/i] lite, but it does have its own character.  It doesn't offer the same amount of depth, and I ultimately question its replay value over time, which is why I didn't rate it as highly.  It looks great, is easy to teach, comes in a very attractive and portable tin, and can quickly scratch your itch for a cooperative game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is a solid title, that when expanded upon, will become a standout one.

Family night friendly!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
A simple game but gentle family fun and I just like the vibe of the game so am happy to play it. It may be a little too simple for some folks but do try some of the more exotic layouts for the tiles, like a circular island. A really good game to introduce people to modern games. They may not have seen a co-operative game before and the idea of a map that sinks/forming a custom board is cool too. In terms of co-op for gamers, I prefer the slightly more meaty Forbidden Desert, which has a cool mechanic of sand drifting around and burying tiles deeper and deeper and a feeling that it is really in danger of literally burying you in sand.

My fave though in the family co-op stakes from Matt Leacock is Thunderbirds. Longer to play and a little bit deeper than Desert, and I have fun flying around in the crazy vehicles. May appeal to the big kid in you. Like Patchwork, it was bought to play with my son but having experienced it, I would now buy it for myself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very intriguing cooperative game that borrows some of the mechanisms of Pandemic, yet manages to capture its own unique feel.  The production quality of this game is amazing.  The chunky tiles have great art on them, the cards are all well laminated, and the treasure tokens are just amazing quality.  This would be a great introductory cooperative game, as the mechanisms are very simple yet the game can still be quite challenging.

I love the fact that the game is fast to set up and plays in 15 minutes to a half hour at the most.  It will really attract young people, but has enough decisions that it can entertain adults as well.  Watching the island slowly disappear under the adventurers is very cool and actually brings the theme to life.  I may enjoy other cooperative games more, but if I'm limited on time this one is a superb alternative.  And don't let the younger age range, faster play time, and simpler mechanisms fool you...this game can be a real challenge to win even on the normal difficulty level.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great intro to co-op gaming

I'd go on to get rid of this because I have Pandemic.

RATING: 6.5
A very simple co-op, similar to Pandemic but even simpler. It has to be said, I wasn't particularly turned on by this one, it seemed very easy at novice and normal levels and is so simple that the randomness just shines through. For example, the placement of the helicopter tile in the middle makes for a much easier game, for another, pick up all 3 'waters rise' cards early and you will struggle. Pick them up late and things will be easy.

Pandemic does this better.

RATING: 6
Good, light, fun. Gamewright x2 copys
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Even though it is derived from Pandemic, a game I sincerely dislike, I really love Forbidden Island: likely it is because it has all I couldn’t find in its forerunner. As a matter of fact Forbidden Island is a thrilling game: the the players really need to cooperate in order to win and, even more important, nobody feels like he’s just a puppet.
While in Pandemic the diversity of roles was discriminant between a fun and a boring play, in Forbidden Island every character is helpful and has always something enthralling to do at every turn, something that looks like it’s an important or decisive move: it’s not just trying to meet with the other players and swap cards (as Pandemic requires).
Forbidden Island is quick and light-hearted enough to warrant a lot of fun: as such, it can appease every category of gamers and is a good choice even as a family game. (October 2011)

[b]Edit[/b] - After intensely playing Forbidden Island, I still enjoy it but I also think my rating is too high for a simple game such this one: thus in July 2012 I adjusted my rating, lowering it from an excessive 9 to a more fitting 8.

RATING: 7
Forbidden Island is explicitly a retheme and simplification of Pandemic by the same designer; the game is meant to appeal to a younger audience and families. That said, this might end up hitting the table more often than Pandemic even with no youngsters around. The laying out of the tiles is quick and simple and makes for what seems to be more like a puzzle to be solved than a set of overwhelming problems to be contained. The theme likewise suggests more of a sense of adventure than a feeling of hopeless dread. Pandemic is without doubt a deeper game, but Forbidden Island might be a game that I associate more with the good mood I find myself in when I play it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
30 plays: Great little cooperative game, perfectly tuned for narrow losses and victories, which makes for a great feeling. Easy to take off the shelf, easy to set up, and great to look at. There's a real feeling of drama as the island disappears!

Always fun, but doesn't have that deeper level of satisfaction that Settlers does for me. My daughter enjoyed it at 5, but didn't really understand how to pick her moves until 10 plays in. Definitely suffers from Alpha Player syndrome, where clever players have to resist bossing everyone else around.

Wonderful visual design, though I wish at times that the different tiles actually did different things to reflect their mysterious names and artwork!

Probably the game we play most often at the moment of this writing! And a perfect gateway game for non-gamers.

Note: there is an unofficial expansion card set that is excellent.

RATING: 4
Pandemic rethemed and made lighter/simpler. Bits are nice, game isn't.

Decisions are rather obvious - there is no angst here (unlike Pandemic where you might want to use a card for movement and to save for a cure). Tension you have in pandemic just isn't here - you can let most of the island sink with litte problem, the game feels like you are just waiting for the sets of cards to come out.

If I'd played this before Pandemic I'd have thought it was novel, as it is Pandemic does everything better, this is just dull.

RATING: 7
Es un juego colaborativo que utiliza roles. Cada personaje tiene una habilidad especial, y deben combinarse los personajes para conseguir escapar de la isla antes de que se hunda por completo.

Muy del estilo de pandemic, pero simplificado al máximo. Es un juego sencillo y muy rapido (30 minutos), hasta cuatro jugadores. Es muy familiar y facil de jugar con no jugones.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
OTro juego que originariamente era de PAtri y se lo pedí allá por el 2015, me lo dejó y acabó diciéndome que me lo quedara.
Es un juego cooperativo, sencillito, en el que hasta cuatro jugadores tienen que colaborar, cada uno aportando las cualidades de su personaje para recuperar cuatro tesoros de una isla antes de que se hunda por completo (el motor del juego va elevando el nivel del agua).
Es sencillo y apto para no jugones.
Se presenta en caja metálica y con buenos componetes.
Se juega en media hora. 
PAra los jugones se queda un poco corto.

Se lo devolví a Patri el 1 de Enero de 2018. Lo había llevado para nochevieja, que no le jugamos al final.. y bueno, en casa, tampoco lo usé demasiado.

One concern, like Pandemic - or any other cooperative game, it is that dominant personalities can play the game out at the expense of weaker players (telling others what to do as opposed to playing with them).

RATING: 5

EDIT:

After few plays more I have to admit that this game has a real issue with the difficulty level. Game is much too easy to be a lasting co-op.

RATING: 4
It's Pandemic Light, which is saying something since Pandemic is already a light game.  I guess Forgotten Island is meant to be a family-oriented version of Pandemic but I don't see the value in it.  The theme might be more appealing to some families, but the gameplay is so much simpler that deciding what to do on your turn is obvious because there are so few elements to deal with.  The simplicity robs the game of tension because you never have to take a risk.  Without tension, the game is boring.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm not sure this game is not an eight, but I'm not sure it's not a 10 either.  I am sure this is a game everyone, theme haters included, should own.  First the price, at $10.00-$15.00 there is no defensible reason to not own it.  Skip the value meal and eat bologna for a day, BAM hours of entertainment gained.  Second the value is likely unmatched at any price.  The quality of the components (box/tray), the artwork, the whole physical package is absolutely stunning.  Aside from that it is challenging (at least 1/2 dozen games before we won one...) and fun to play, takes very little time to get the hang of and is probably the best intro to cooperative gaming there is.  Is it the most fun I've ever had, would I rather play it than anything else...no but again at $10.00 if I never play it again (unlikely) it has repaid me in fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It's true, I definitely enjoy Pandemic much more for the added nuance (i.e., complexity). But Forbidden Island is great for playing with mixed groups or with kids. Games that work well for adults and kids playing together are actually extremely rare, and good ones are rarer still. True "gateway" games that can really engage both hobbyists and non-hobbyists in the same game are similarly scarce, but Forbidden Island manages it and you can reasonably expect to convert a few people to Pandemic Legacy.

For what it's trying to do and who it's aimed at, I actually think this is a better game than Pandemic. For gamers, just go right to the highest difficulty levels, which should engage even hardened coop veterans. The many good expansions do give Pandemic much higher replayability, but Forbidden Island will clearly have broader appeal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After 2 plays:
A reimplementation and simplification of the popular co-op Pandemic by designer Matt Leacock. The theme has been changed from curing diseases to escaping a sinking island with fabulous treasure to make it more family friendly (cue Indiana Jones music), but much of the core mechanics remain: players are trying to collect sets of cards from one deck (to cure diseases/find treasures) while another deck is getting drawn from at an increasing rate to make their situation more tenuous (spreading diseases/sinking the island). While both games are marked 10-and-up, the steamlining and simplification has taken this from a game that a 10-year-old could be taught to a game that a group of motivated 10-year-olds could pick up and learn on their own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Has quickly become a classic favorite right next to Ticket to Ride...
My 10yr old and 8 yr old love this!  I love that they learn to work together, learn risk management, and decision making skills.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
While I really enjoy Pandemic this version just simplifies it too much for me.  It's essentially the exact same game, but stripped down and set to a slightly different feel.

The kicker for me is that there were several turns where it was in our best interest to do absolutely nothing.  If you give me three actions per turn, and I don't need any of them half the time, the tension that makes the entire game fun just flat out disappears.  Maybe it was due to a fortuitous layout, shuffle, or combination of special abilities, but we were content to let most of the island sink and were never even remotely in danger of losing, and this was on the 2nd hardest setting.  The game literally was an exercise in sitting around waiting to draw the right cards.

Overall, I'd probably think this was fun had Pandemic not come first.  As it is, I would probably only play this if I wanted a Pandemic-like game to play with kids or people that can handle very very few rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Hard to beat but really fun to play.

Rienk
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game suffers from a common issue that plagues many coop games - its only fun when you are on the edge of loosing. Any moves you propose are discussed/approved by the entire group, which makes all of the moves near perfect, but also make the game very dull. You not really in a control of your own character - the group is in control of all characters at once. After a while it becomes a situation when you can safely go out for a drink/smoke/pizza, and the group will keep managing your character to the best of its ability without any real need for your participation. And yeah you can play this game completely solo.
Art is very pretty though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
OK game but too simplistic. It's not easy to win though. Good as an introduction
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Has a lot of similar mechanics to Pandemic but slightly more simplified.  You're on a a sinking island and have to collect 4 artifacts and escape before you're stranded.  Fully co-operative.  Would definitely suggest as a good introductory co-op game to those ho haven't played one before.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Eindhoven
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A nice cooperative game that is perfect to introduce new players to this type of game. The game contains a lot of the same mechanisms found in Pandemic (and its big brother Forbidden Desert) but keeps decisions simple. Components are nice and the game contains in a really nice tin box. As an experienced gamer I would rather play Pandemic over this one but I think this one may work better for non-gamers at first or to introduce older children to cooperative games.

A light co-op with limited replayability. Strictly a gateway game--but a successful one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With over a hundred plays of Pandemic, and with Forbidden Island using the same engine, I will likely always compare the two.

Forbidden Island is simpler with fewer rules, quicker set-up, fewer in-play options, which makes it my goto game for those who rarely play board games. But, it is also swingier due to just shuffling in the water rises cards and how at some points you will end up going through the entire location deck without drawing a water rises card.

It's a very good game, I just own better coöps. With more time, Pandemic is always better. Otherwise, for the cool theme there's Escape, and for the easy rules there's Hanabi.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
2-4 players

Loved this game for many game sessions, but my wife and I started to notice a trend that we would tell new players how to play when we didn4-player, and that one of us would tell the other how to play when we did 2-player. In the end, this game often feels like a 1-player game with 4 people. It suffers from the alpha dog problem that so many cooperative games have. 

Great game; a true pioneer in cooperative play. It’s mechanics are now found in many coops, although the newest coops try to break the alpha dog problem in one way or another.

RATING: 8
I really like this game. Originally I rated it as a 10. Over time my opinion and rating has gone down for a couple of reasons.

First, it is very much like Pandemic mechanically and while I love Pandemic, this gets a little "same-y" especially after 16 plays of Pandemic Legacy last year.

Secondly, there is a strategy where, at low player counts, you can just camp on a few tiles around the landing pad and let the rest of the island sink. You'll usually win with this strategy, but I believe this was fixed to some degree with Forbidden Desert.

Still a great game that we played as a family many, many times.

RATING: 10
A perfect little co-op game for the price. Takes 20-30 minutes to play, and has adjustable levels of difficulty. I introduced my girlfriend to this game, and she loved it. 

One word of advice: if you're finding the game too easy, check out the European rules for the game. They include a number of different possible formations for the island that really increase the game's difficulty. For under $20, you can't go wrong with this game.

RATING: 6
Played with my 6 year old and while she started getting it by the end I still think it’s a bit beyond her which is the only way this gets played in my house. I’d rather play Ghost Fightin Treasure Hunters with her as Forbidden Island was mostly about moving and shoring up tiles with the hope of getting the right card draws each turn. Not much game here for me honestly and there are definitely more fun family games out there than this.

A couple more plays and it's slightly better. One game ended within 3 rounds the other was down to 1 draw of 2 cards and we lost both. So the game has now shown me a bit more range, and while it is harder than some of the other cooperative games my daughter likes to play, she does seem okay with losing which is good.

RATING: 7.49
Forbidden Island is a nice little cooperative game. Components are well made, and seems to play well. That being said, I'm not as hyped over it as I was Pandemic. The play is interesting and keeps you on your toes. It is strange not having a board to keep track of where the cards belong. As you play they get knocked around a bit and it can sometimes be hard to tell the empty spaces. This is really not a big deal, but it does distract some from the esthetic. Overall a good little game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great game for player interaction, everyone have a different role to play in the game and everyone has a different view on the best strategy to win as a team. Best when everyone is willing to listen to the group and come to a consensus, could get annoying if one person tries to take charge though.
There are several difficulty levels to make sure there is always a challenge. We have a lot of fun with two players, but we need to play on the harder levels, it is a lot more challenging with more people and your strategy will be completely different.
We enjoy seeing the different layouts each time, it is a fun, all be it stressful game and the components are high quality and lovely to look at
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Pandemic's little brother. Pretty good little game that looks great and is well themed.  The Forbidden Island is sinking and players must co-operate to collect the four treasures, make it to the helicopter pad and escape before the island disappears into the sea.  How cool is that?! We enjoy the way the tension builds as the island starts sinking faster than your ability to stop it.  The luck factor could turn some people off, but as a family game it is great fun.

RATING: 7.5
[b]AVOID THE RULES[/b] ([COLOR=#FF0000][b]A V[/b][/COLOR]ideo [COLOR=#FF0000][b]O[/b][/COLOR]f [COLOR=#FF0000][b]I[/b][/COLOR]nstruction & [COLOR=#FF0000][b]D[/b][/COLOR]emonstration [COLOR=#0000FF][b]T[/b][/COLOR]hat [COLOR=#0000FF][b]H[/b][/COLOR]elps [COLOR=#0000FF][b]E[/b][/COLOR]ase [COLOR=#FF0000][b]R[/b][/COLOR]ule [COLOR=#FF0000][b]U[/b][/COLOR]nderstanding & [COLOR=#FF0000][b]L[/b][/COLOR]earning - [COLOR=#FF0000][b]E[/b][/COLOR]asy [COLOR=#FF0000][b]S[/b][/COLOR]tart!)

[u]BGG:[/u] http://boardgamegeek.com/video/37425/forbidden-island/forbidden-island-avoid-the-rules-by-connect-more
[u]YouTube:[/u] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0W4STfNaMNA

[u]Summary sheet[/u] for educators that highlights the circullum ties and educational benefits of Forbidden Island: [filepage=97639][/filepage]

[thing=65244][/thing] is an aesthetically pleasing [b]cooperative[/b] game where everyone must work together to capture all four treasures on the island and escape on their helicopter before the island and its treasures are reclaimed by the ocean never to be seen again. 

Each player represents and controls a different adventurer, each with a special ability [b](variable player powers)[/b], on an expedition team. On your turn, you are allowed to take up to 3 actions [b](action point allowance system)[/b] including movement [b](grid movement)[/b] on the[b] modular board[/b], information/card sharing [b](set collection)[/b], shore up, or you can find a treasure.

RATING: 5
Pandemic Streamlined.  When I need a faster game, I choose this one.

Again, there is randomness, but like pandemic, I like the recycle of the sink pile to intensify the tension in the game.  I think this is an elegant solution to the randomness, though I see that some find it a cheap cop-out.  My biggest gripe is that there are some really useful roles (pilot) and some not so really useful roles.  Perhaps better balancing between roles would help the game?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
In VERY vague terms it's an easier / family friendly pandemic, but why?  There are a great many games that are both easier than pandemic and fun, so why play this one?  The fun of pandemic is strategy, risk / reward, and choice.  This game has very little nuance.  This game barely needs human beings to control the actions, just look for the flooded tiles, get there in as few moves as possible, and flip them back over. Focus on flipping High Value tiles back over and not getting your dude stuck.  Done.... that's the whole game.  Just not enough there AND it just doesn't have a soul.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Played a number of games solo (simulating 2 players). Best game that can be played solo I have played so far, and can see it is a good gateway co-op game. 

Managed to win reasonably comfortably on the novice and normal level, and managed to win three times on the elite level. Gave the legendary level a go, and the engineer and the messenger came close, but just lost one of the temples before the relic could be retrieved. The higher levels really bring the requirement to use the special power well in combination, although there is still a very large luck factor based on the order of the water level rising coming out. 

Too complex to play with my daughter just yet, but maybe in another couple of years. Will bring this one out as a good co-op gateway game in a family setting. 

27/12/14 - played this again and won on legendary level with the pilot and the engineer. Did it I first go so may have just got unlucky previously (or I wasn't using the right character combos).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.5
This is one of the first board games I ever bought and still has some of the best artwork in my collection. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is an excellent family game.  Easy enough for the kid to pick up, but with enough tactical analysis and bet-hedging to keep the adults playing and amused.  The cooperative nature of the game is perfect for the family, too, because it doesn't matter if the adults "play better" than the kids -- everyone's working together.  And we discovered by accident how easy it is to tweak the difficulty -- you can start the game with fewer (or no) already-sinking cards, you can avoid the "instant reshuffle" after the "Waters Rise" cards...  And it still ends up a fun game with cinematic tension.

RATING: 7
Pandemic meets Raiders of the Lost Ark!  While Pandemic is a great game, it just didn't strike a chord with my kids who love to play cooperative games.  It also proved much too fiddly for my non-gamer parents.  Forbidden Island fills the gap perfectly as it distills some of the great card mechanics of Pandemic into a package that's very accessible to kids and non-gamers alike at a price point that's very palatable.  Highly recommended -- I think this will make a great birthday gift for some of my son's pals!

Olv
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Pandemic Light. No more awkward card passing rules, no more snowball outbreaks, no more tricky special player powers (read: no Dispatcher), very limited special action cards (just sandbags and a helicopter lift), and a much less threathening subject in this post 9/11-world: treasure hunting.

As I write this Pandemic hasn't been out of its box in well over 18 months or so (it's been pre-empted by other titles, and not because I think it bad or because I’m done with it), but I really wouldn’t want to put Forbidden Island on the table instead as a ‘shorter Pandemic’ to satisfy the coop appetite. Although I think I understand why Matt Leacock would create this simplified edition, which is perfect for elderly children and less fanatical gaming groups, I am very respectfully going to bow out of this one. I feel it is not kind to him to award this game with this low a number; but I promise I will make up by speaking highly of this game when not-too-serious gamers are looking for an interesting new title.

Before I forget: what Forbidden Island [i]did[/i] get absolutely right, just as its predecessor Pandemic, is the lack of randomness in player actions. Everything you do as a player is going to happen as you envisaged it. It's not like Hexer von Salem or Ghost Stories or Yggdrasil where randomly occurring shit limits what happens during your actual action. Thank you for that, Matt.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of my top recommendations for kids/families.

RATING: 10
J-B-3
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Really wished I had gone with Pandemic, got this idea that is was some grander, complex game. It isn't, Forbidden Island is just watered down, Forbidden Desert a step up, of the two Forbidden Desert is the better pick.

The problem with Pandemic is the MSRP and the base game isn't that much more over Forbidden Desert. Pandemic needs that In the Lab expansion to make it shine above the Forbidden series. Problem here is that is another $40 MSRP and the Lab Challenge is the only useable part, the rest expanses On the Brink, yet another $30 MSRP.

The Lab Challenge does away with the 5 card by one player collection cure, makes it a multi co-op step action. Basically makes it a little easy to collect the cards, but adds multi steps. It is a nice mechanism.

It is a shame Z-Man when it reissued the new 2013 edition of Pandemic it didn't include the Lab Challenge given the retail price and the base game needed a boost.


if you can pick up the 2013 Pandemic base game for $20, On the Brink for $25, for $45 I guess it is OK, for way less Forbidden Desert will do you.

This guy just does a lot of rehashing.

What a perfect gateway game to pull out with any group!  Well worth adding to our collection.

RATING: 5
Components: Nice artwork on the tiles, and fun artifact pawns. The graphic design, consistent with other Gamewright titles, leaves a lot to be desired.

Experience: Very similar to Pandemic. Because the game's AI is mostly random, there is barely any opportunity for strategy. Just move around shoring up tiles and collecting cards. Not very interesting. Any tension comes from immersing myself in the theme, imagining that the island really is sinking beneath me.

First Played: 2011-06-25
Last Played: 2014-12-07
Plays (3):
2 players: 1
3 players: 1
5 players: 1

The same designer as Pandemic, with a similar game mechanism.  I highly recommend this one.  I have lent it to Al Chant in the past.  Challenging.  There is a sequel to this game, called Forbidden Desert, but I can't justify buying it for ~$35 to get basically the same game as this one.

RATING: 6
Very light game. The Gamewright marketing text, to us anyway, comically overstates the "electrifying tension" etc. that Forbidden Island brings to the table. As gamers will recognize, this is just Pandemic with stripped-down mechanics and a different theme. It's neither a bad game nor a great game. It's a good crossover title, but I would personally almost always want to play Pandemic instead... especially with it's expansion.

RATING: 6
My 9-year old likes this game, as do I. The bits are beautiful and the game-play is intense (for casual gamers). Our 5-year old "plays" with us, but the strategy is beyond her. Fortunately, the co-op nature of the game allows her to tag along and feel part of the team right up to the end. It makes for a fun evening activity for us all.

This game doesn't get played as much as I thought it would in our house, it is distinctly less popular with the kids than Survive (Escape from Atlantis) and Journey to the Center of the Earth. Usually, I have to cajole the kids to play this instead. I still really like it, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Forbidden Island is a light cooperative game. The players must gather four treasures and escape the island with a helicopter before it sinks. Forbidden Island is frequently compared to Pandemic and for a good reason. They are strikingly similar. If you like Pandemic you will probably like Forbidden Island as well. It is not quite as meaty of an experience as Pandemic is, but on the positive side, it is easier to teach and to learn. And it looks great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Most definitely Pandemic Lite; not necessarily a bad thing, but there's no escaping a "been there, done that" feeling. Pandemic fans looking for the next-great-new co-op experience won't find it here. 

Ideal if you're in the mood for something quicker than a full game of Pandemic or perhaps a game slightly less challenging. Probably the more ideal gateway co-op of the two for the non-gamer. Went over pretty well with my inlaws.

I'm not sure yet if seeing ever-disappearing island tiles evokes more panic than a global pox spreading epidemically out of control, but there's certainly tension.

Ugrading to an 8.5 because of how great a gateway game this has turned out to be.

2018: Have ended up raising the score from a 6.5 to a 7. This game is incredibly fun to play with both adults and even more so with young kids. My son was 5 when we first played this with him and he loved it!

RATING: 6
I really enjoy playing Forbidden Island with my family. Being a cooperative game, however, it does not work well with all types of crowds and for me it hits the table with only certain family members. Many of my family and friends tend to like the competitive nature of board games, and cooperative games just don't do it. What I love about Forbidden Island is its inexpensive prices tag, its portability, and the different roles that make the group have to approach each game with a different strategy. Overall, great game!

RATING: 6
It's a good game, but not all I had hoped. I've played with two and three players, and while the mechanics are great, the difficulty/tension doesn't seem to quite work out in many games. Winning or losing often comes down to a card draw at the end of a game which our strategy has no apparent effect on. This is disappointing because you don't feel you could have played better somehow to overcome the issue. The solutions are usually obvious when they're available. I understand that this is the "family" version of Pandemic, in many senses, but I had hoped, based on other reviews, that it would be good for adults too. It's a clever game, but it has quickly moved to the bottom of the pile.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Excellent cooperative game with high stakes and highly customizable difficulty level, and a bit easier than Forbidden Desert. This gives off the same vibes as Pandemic, i.e. you always feel like several things are working against you and pressuring you into quickly & efficiently completing your objectives, which is the key to making a great cooperative game. The element components themselves are uniquely cool--in fact the quality of all that you get is incredible for the affordable price. The excitement, range of options, and accessibility to new players makes it one of the best cooperative games out there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Yep. It's Pandemic lite but still fun and quite a bit quicker. This game doesn't play out in the variety of ways that Pandemic, depending on the roles, can. You get pretty much the same experience regardless of the characters in play. Card exchange matters much more in this game than in Pandemic and, fortunately, is easier to pull off. The treasure cards in Forbidden Island are scarce enough that you won't win even at the novice level without some exchanges, whereas it's possible to win two-player Pandemic without ever exchanging cards. Anyway, at $16.00, this is a Best Buy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Forbidden Island is one of the best cooperative games on the market.  It is also one of the simplest of the cooperative games, which makes it great for introducing to people who are not familiar with the genre.

I might like this better than Pandemic (which is saying a lot).  I like that the rules are cleaner, but I'm not as big of a fan of the theme.  So I'm torn.  It'll probably take a while of playing with gamers and non-gamers before I fully decide which one is my favorite.

--EDIT--
Increased my rating from 7.5 to 8.  This game is much more fun to play with the wife and relatives than Pandemic.  Pandemic is simply one level too deep for many non-gamers.

--EDIT--
Reduced my rating to a 7.  It turns out that my wife doesn't really like it.  If I can only get this to the table with gamers, then I might as well play Pandemic.

RATING: 5
Game plays a lot like Pandemic except the theme isn't as good.  You're basically just flipping cards to get 4 of a kind...trading w/other players...when you are on the same spot.  Then you flip the timer deck which randomizes how long you have to collect your 4 of a kinds.  I'd play it again if asked, but wouldn't seek it out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Players cooperate to extract four treasures from an island, and escape, before the island sinks beneath the ocean.  Simple game where players take three actions - move, exchange treasure cards, extract a treasure, or "shore" up the island tile to delay its sinking.  Then, treasure cards are drawn, the island sinks a little more, and repeat over again.  Very light, delightfully presented, and totally derivative cooperative game using the do good then do evil mechanic.  This one is aimed directly at families, and for that, it works well.  Gamers should look at the meatier Pandemic (which shares a lot of common ground).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Cooperative game about gathering four treasures on a rapidly-sinking island.  Players will frantically run around the island trying to control the flooding, before (if they get this far!) making a mad dash for the helicopter at the end of the game.  Similar to Pandemic, but faster and easier to learn.

RATING: N/A
Bought after seeing on Tabletop. Have really enjoyed playing, although one of the first things I did was print out the cards for the variant island layouts. Our record is currently 2-3 and have lost in two different ways so far. We lost with a flooded Fool's Landing, and we lost when the flood gauge got all the way to the top. The games we've won have seemed to be when the various temple areas are close to Fool's Landing and also when Fool's Landing comes up very late in the set of island tiles that get flooded. We've never won without the Pilot card. We've lost with the Pilot, but never won without it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game uses the same dynamic as Pandemic where you spend most of your time collecting colored cards and racing around trying to accomplish your mission before the world ends. Instead of a horrible virus (Pandemic) there is this island sinking and you have to collect 4 ancient treasures and make it back to the helipad before the island sinks. I used to play Survive! when I was a kid and this reminds me a little of it. But mostly, its kind of a rip off Pandemic. Still fun and totally coop, which is rare in board games.

RATING: 4
Played at Birmingham Expo 2010.
I thought it better than Pandemic. 
The end-race to the helicopter pad was good fun, but the start game was boring.  Spiced up a little as the flooded sections started being lost. I think it would have been more exciting if there were no special powers allowing eg Pilot to move anywhere for 1 action. I suppose it would be easy to make-up and apply a different set of player-specific capabilities.  I would also have liked something more to do with the treasure cards once that treasure had been collected - eg maybe the cards are treasure + gold coins - and so when gold coins could be 'stashed' outside of the hand?  This would also let you add a bit of distinction between players to see which person actually won!

RATING: 4
One day I WILL win this game!  So far I am 0-2 in the 2P game. 

Update: after 6 games, I FINALLY won FI in a 4p game.  Winning did nothing to change my opinion of the game.  If anything, it seemed so incredibly easy that it just pissed me off more that it took that many games to be successful.  

Perhaps it's the way we play.  We always randomize the roles at the beginning of the game and that can really make the game difficult.  

I'm not ready to completely give up on this one as it's short, easy to pick up, and will probably be a hit with my kids.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Matt Leacock's design aesthetic is immediately apparent in this game. The accelerating rate of the constantly sinking island, and the various roles are streamlined from Pandemic. This streamlining makes for a much simpler game, but also feels like a major step backward. The game hinges too strongly on the timing of the 'Waters Rise' cards. A few too early, or a few too closely together can make the game unbeatable even with optimal play, which feels more frustrating that challenging. Despite all of the changes I still find Pandemic to be much more enjoyable, but if you are a Leacock fan looking for a shorter and easier experience, this is your game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[2 plays] I came to this game after being pretty familiar with Pandemic, and that has totally colored my viewpoint on it.  I find it next to impossible to assess Forbidden Island in a vacuum or say what I would have thought about it without Pandemic, but in comparison to Pandemic, I found it pretty underwhelming.  

Mechanically, it’s a watered-down Pandemic, and I didn’t see any need to water it down.  And the vague attempt at a theme here is pretty weak next to the gritty realism of Pandemic.  I know some people have found the real-world plague theme off-putting, but I find it interesting and productive of the tension and suspense the game needs.  In Forbidden Island, we were just some adventurers looking to harvest treasure and get off the island before it sank.  What island is this, and why is it forbidden?  Who are we and why are we here?  What are these treasures and how do we know about them?  Why don’t we have the sense to escape the island without all the treasure we came for if it’s a choice between that and perishing?  None of these questions seemed to have an answer.  

I should say, as a huge caveat to my remarks, that I have not read the rulebook to this game.  I learned it from others who knew how to play.  So it’s entirely possible that the people teaching me just left out a bunch of thematic stuff that did exist (which in my experience is an all too common occurrence).  It’s also possible that there are answers to the rules questions that came up during our session--although the experienced players did have the rulebook and were looking at it for answers.  (Of course, sometimes in the middle of playing a game, you try to look up some rule and don’t find it and give up, only to discover later when you take more time that the issue was indeed addressed somewhere else in the rules.)  I was astonished, though, at the lacunae in the rules for such a simple game.  We came across several issues that were not made clear.  

On a positive note, production standards are high (the treasures look like something from Days of Wonder!), and I thought the tile art was lovely.  

This game does share one feature with Pandemic that I dislike, which is that roles are tied to player color.  What that means for me is that if I pick by color, I’m always stuck in the same role, but if I pick by role--or, more likely, if we assign roles randomly--then I can’t be my preferred color, and may spend half the game wrongfully trying to move the green piece.

Forbidden Island is an innocuous game, and I wouldn’t hate to play it again.  However, given a choice, I would always choose Pandemic.  And if I were going to play a game the length of Forbidden Island (FI is shorter than Pandemic), I would always choose something else.  

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Card Game, COOP
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Forbidden Island is a visually stunning cooperative board game. Instead of winning by competing with other players like most games, everyone must work together to win the game. Players take turns moving their pawns around the 'island', which is built by arranging the many beautifully screen-printed tiles before play begins. As the game progresses, more and more island tiles sink, becoming unavailable, and the pace increases. Players use strategies to keep the island from sinking, while trying to collect treasures and items. As the water level rises, it gets more difficult- sacrifices must be made.

What causes this game to truly stand out among co-op and competitive games alike is the extreme detail that has been paid to the physical components of the game. It comes in a sturdy and organized tin of good shelf storage size. The plastic treasure pieces and wooden pawns are well crafted and they fit just right into the box. The cards are durable, well printed, and easy to understand. The island tiles are the real gem: they are screen-printed with vibrant colors, each with a unique and pleasing image.
With multiple levels of difficulty, different characters to choose from (each with a special ability of their own), many optional island formats and game variations available, Forbidden Island has huge replay value. The game can be played by as few as two players and up to four (though it can accommodate five). More players translates into a faster and more difficult game, though the extra help can make all the difference. This is a fun game, tricky for players of almost any age. Selling for under twenty dollars, oddly, Forbidden Island is a rare game of both quality and affordable price.

RATING: 8
[b]Rating based on - 25+ plays, 2 player[/b]
This is the very first game I bought when I got into board games a year ago. The artwork is just stunning and I love the theme and the various pieces. What's more is that it comes in a cool tin which stacks well with Revolver 2. LOVE! Excellent components at an even more excellent price. I think we played correctly the first few times, then we put it away to play new games, and when it came out again it felt just as difficult as the first few times. Turns out we were forgetting to deal out the initial cards. Recommend that method to make it more difficult. Also recommend the various tile layouts and role variants posted on BGG - https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/569926/official-variant-tile-layouts 
https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/912996/forbidden-island-variant-listing
https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/974336/surreal-artwork-variant-tiles-treasure-powers-new

I would not get Pandemic if it plays just like this one. I actually LIKE this one. Why would I want something that replaces it or plays just like it? I have heavier co-ops like Dead Men Tell No Tales or Ghost Stories for more challenge when I need it. This one is great as an intro to co-ops, or if you want a lighter or quicker playing co-op. Recommend! Especially with all of the fan-made expansions to keep it fresh...

RATING: 8
Call it Pandemic Lite. Forbidden Island is by the same designer and employs the same concepts of cooperative play, racing against the clock and player specialties you can leverage to achieve victory. My 7yo son enjoys the treasure-collecting theme (he insists on holding onto all the treasures we capture) and is able to do a pretty good job at thinking through his options and is beginning to grasp how we can work together to win. As you master the game, you'll find you will nearly always win on the starter difficulty level, and it's nice that you can easily increase the challenge when you are ready.

Also check out the iOS adaptation. It's very well done.

RATING: 8
I confess - I like co-op games.

This is a great game that can be played within 20 to 30 minutes by yourself, with another person, or even with a small group.  Quick setup.  Nice and durable components that fit into a smaller tin allowing you to easily pack it as part of your family travels.

Relatively easy concept & mechanics that allows for younger children to play and participate.  Variable difficulty setting that you can set depending on the skill level of the players.

Like several others, I consider this a lighter version of Pandemic.

RATING: 5.3

I think this game will be relegated to playing with children starting about 6.

On Bruno Faidutti's Best Games List.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Pros
-simple cooperative game, easy to teach and easy to get casual players to play (more so than Forbidden Desert)
-short game, can play several times if you fail, easy setup
-decent replayability (random layout of map)
-adjustable difficulty
-different character roles (more than the maximum number of players)
-sufficient options during a turn

Cons
-prone to alpha gamer
-not very deep, what to do is usually fairly obvious
-not much to do on first turn of game (but action picks up quickly)
-very few special ability treasure cards (only sandbag and helicopter)
-low player limit (only up to 4 players)
-not a fan of the collect cards, trade cards, move to get treasure (so obviously immigrated from Pandemic)
-moderate degree of luck involved in draw 
-water rises is tied to treasure cards drawn, but locations sinking is not (e.g. you can draw a water rises card, which shuffles the locations that sink and then instantly draw the same sinking location in a previous turn and instantly die without being able to do anything).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The changing spatial element, simple flooding mechanic, and simplified card-passing rules appeal to me. The art and components are great too. Nevertheless it's simpler and probably less replayable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Since I started playing Ghost Stories last September, the world of cooperative playing opened up to me, so I bought me a couple more, of which I now tried and enjoyed Forbidden Island. Though the experience is quite different from Ghost Stories (less brainburning), I originally rated it the same. Strongest points compared to Ghost Stories are the short & easy gameplay and modular board. But it's less of a challenge and becomes more repetitive after a while. After I played Pandemic, I had to lower to an 8.

RATING: 7
Rules Complexity: :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth: :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Luck Factor :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::star::star:
Player Interaction: :star::star::star::star::star:
"Take That" Conflict: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:

This is only very slightly easier to learn than Pandemic (which isn't difficult itself), but is so much more fun to play with kids.  The components are absolutely top-notch.  It's so easy to fall into telling a story about the sinking island while playing, and I would say there's about as much tension as Pandemic.  While the box says 10+, many 6 or 7 year-olds I know could play this.

RATING: 3
I only played this once. This cooperative game has similar mechanics to Pandemic but is much simpler: purely about tactics this turn or the next (whereas Pandemic has more interesting decisions that can have ramifications many turns later). Forbidden Island is so simple that I didn't want to play a second game. I could see this being a nice game for 4-6 year olds but that's about it. If you're an older kid or adult, I would not recommend this game for a first cooperative game - Pandemic is far more interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.8
Very fun cooperative game. The mechanics are very straight-forward and it flows really well. The setup time is also small when compared to Pandemic.

However, after getting the hang of this game it feels like you're just standing around waiting for cards. Pandemic shares this, but I usually feel like that's lost towards the middle of the game. Forbidden Island doesn't lose it until almost the very end.

In the end I feel that this game plays much smoother than Pandemic, but it has slightly less depth and tension.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
While simpler than any of the other cooperative games by this designer, the game has the most even difficulty curve. Each other game in the trilogy the overall difficulty seems to come about from nothing but pure chance, but this one manages to be just about equally challenging each time it is played (not that poor luck cannot undermine a run).
The game suffers from the major problems with alpha gaming, so it is still hard to recommend over better cooperative titles.

RATING: 7
A light, family version of Pandemic.  The core mechanics are the same if not a bit streamlined.  I think there is sufficient difference between the two to warrant owning both.  The production values are outstanding and it is difficult to see how they could make a profit selling it at this price.  If you like co-op games (especially if you have younger gamers), this one is a must own.

PROS:

-Cada partida es diferente gracias al uso de distintos personajes y a la disposición cambiante de las losetas en el tablero (además de las formas adicionales de la isla)
-Se puede jugar en solitario
-Relación calidad/precio muy buena
-La cuna es muy buena

RATING: 6
Good way to bring Pandemic mechanics to the younger crowd. Too luck-driven for adult play, but probably one of the better games to actually play with kids.  They can actually handle this and have a good time!  Though it's funny (and expected) to see the dominant leader come out of the game. Fortunately, kids don't always mind being told what to do in this context and once they have a handle on the mechanics, they begin to make better decisions for themselves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played first time last night with the parents and we loved it. Great fun, there are interesting options for choices to be made and discussed. The island really got sinking heavily after we collected the final treasure, which gave it the 'Raiders of the Lost Ark rush to escape with our lives' feeling.

The only down side is that I'm an advanced gamer and my parents aren't so familiar with the more modern games, so they were often making unhelpful choices which I would counter with more beneficial ones. The next time around I'll step back and let them drive, win or lose. That's the best way to learn!

All in all, a fantastic family game which is simple to learn and a lot of fun.

RATING: 5
Førstehåndsindtrykket af Forbidden Island vil jeg sige var godt. Der er tale om et lækkert produceret spil, der kan anskaffes til en meget rimelig pris. Efter at have spillet det en del gange må jeg dog indrømme, at jeg finder det ret trivielt. Forlægget, Pandemic, er i mine øjne af en helt anden kvalitet og langt mere interessant. I Forbidden Island er der sjældent nogle reelle valg og da slet ikke nogen interessante. Jeg vil stadig kunne finde på at spille det med børn, men interessen har bestemt klinget af for mit vedkommende. Hertil kan i øvrigt tilføjes at det ikke er fordi jeg ikke bryder mig om samarbejdsspil, tværtimod! Konkurrencen fra andre samarbejdsspil har været benhård og det stiller naturligvis heller ikke Forbidden Island i et bedre lys.

RATING: 8
A much lighter and less stressful Pandemic. Not a whole lot different mechanically, but a lot shorter and more accessible. The most interesting difference is the feeling of the island sinking and parts becoming completely inaccessible as things start to go poorly. The game is much more about knowing what locations are safe to let sink, and focusing on where the treasures are, and keeping your escape route opened.

RATING: 7.5
This is a great one for couples and kids as Forbidden Island is a cooperative game.  The tiles and components are gorgeous, with the exception of the boring wooden player pieces.  If you have a game with more interesting figurines (certain editions of Clue work particularly well) I recommend using those instead for added ascetic appeal.  Varying difficulty levels and clever deck mechanics keep the replayability of this game rather high.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I found this at a thrift store for $1.20.  The cards were still in shrink and all components neatly bagged.  It had clearly never been played.

I've tried Pandemic (designed by the same creator as Forbidden Island) and wasn't overly impressed.  I also tried Scotland Yard, and again, not too impressed.

This game, however, I REALLY liked.  It has some of the same elements of Pandemic (as in certain occupations and thus skill set each player can have), but what really works for this game is its simplicity.  I don't mean simplicity in the sense of making it easy, but rather simplicity that allows for easy cooperation among players.  Parts of the island ending up under water and even sinking completely into the water also adds this sense of panic and makes the game more intense to play.  Also, the components are of high quality and practical to allow for smooth game play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
My copy was a gift from a friend. I'm not a cooperative game enthusiast so it was easy to give this away to a student in my high school game club.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I upped my rating a bit for this.
Yes, Pandemic has more strategy, more options, and way more variety with the On the Brink expansion.
But FI is easier to teach, is much more visually appealing, and has a much shorter set-up time and a shorter play time.
On top of that, as others have noted, the ending of FI is superior in many ways.  It is more exciting to have an island sinking than to have cities getting filled, and it is clearly superior to "GET TO DA CHOPPA" than to cure 4 diseases and be done.
I broke down and bought a copy, because it's so pretty, and so cheap.  I still prefer Pandemic, but it's a worthy addition to my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After one game of Forbidden Island with two players, I am rating the game at 7. This game was fun, tense, and interactive as we raced around the island trying to grab the loot before we sank beneath the waves. We made several rules mistakes that were too much to our benefit, so we started over a couple of times. We just barely lost our first game on an unlucky draw when Fool's Landing flooded and sank on the same phase of a turn (we didn't have a Sandbag card to save it). We immediately wanted to play again but were out of time.

This game was our first foray into the co-op experience. It was just wonderful, even though I had to guard against telling my husband what to do. (I have to guard against that temptation in everything we do together!) 

The components are beautifully designed and produced. However, I do not like the metal tin that contains the game because a tin can damage other game boxes around it. Also, the treasures smell bad to me. These complaints are minor, because Forbidden Island has a perfect theme for me. Although I own Pandemic, I have not played it yet and maybe never will. I just can't get past the realistically scary theme because I know how vulnerable our civilization is to plague. 

I want to try this game with my mom, who has low vision, to see if she can see the symbols well enough to tell where to go. My color-blind brother-in-law could probably play too if we substituted markers with symbols for the painted wooden pawns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
