=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Picked this up to play with my (then) 6 y.o. She can generally plan her actions well. My 4 y.o. also like to play along; she moves pawns, draws cards, and gathers treasures, while other plan the actions for her character. It's great to be able to play a more challenging game with older children while still including younger ones.

It's unfortunately very easy to forget to draw cards from the flood deck at the end of each turn.

I found this game getting "samey" after repeated plays. Often looking at the distribution of tiles around the island at the start of the game and the first areas to flood allows for a pretty good prediction of the outcome. Nonetheless, I think the game offers very good value for family play considering it's low cost, and it can serve as a stepping stone to more advanced cooperative games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

The odds are against you but the race against time can be such an adrenalin rush that winning is secondary to playing in this brilliant game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I initially dismissed Forbidden Island. It was being described (accurately) as a simplified Pandemic. Pandemic gets regular play around here, but it's on the lighter end of our preferred range. I didn't see the need for an even lighter version. I thought, "Yeah, I can see a simplified Pandemic being a very successful product in the marketplace, but a game geek like me probably doesn't need to check it out." I was enjoying Pandemic more as it moved into [i]more complex[/i] territory with the introduction of Pandemic: On the Brink, so why bother going in the other direction?

But I was wrong. Forbidden Island creates the same kind of spark as Pandemic. The streamlining does forfeit a bit of the nuance of Pandemic, but it also allows for a sharper and cleaner focus on the core elements that make the game system great. You can probably knock off two games of Forbidden Island for every one game of Pandemic. And this is a game that works very well in that more compact format. I would say that I enjoy Forbidden Island just as much as vanilla Pandemic, because I can play it with a wider variety of people. With gamers, Pandemic with the expansion is definitely the most satisfying version.

I haven't had much success introducing Pandemic to casual gamers and children. It's a light game, but it's a light game for gamers. In other words, it's no Carcassonne or Ticket to Ride; it's Dominion or 7 Wonders. Fobidden Island is a different story altogether. It's approachable in a way that Pandemic is not. It eliminates all the slightly tricky rules pertaining to outbreaks, research stations, and using the cards to travel. It also asks players to display their cards openly, which adds clarity to the game. The lack of private information also makes it abundantly clear that this game is a group puzzle - perhaps making it more vulnerable to a domineering, bossy captain who likes to order everyone around. That's a problem with any of these cooperative games, though, and the best solution is not to play this type of game with that type of personality.

I really enjoy the way that the geography of the island changes every time you play Forbidden Island. Different configurations require different approaches, and I enjoy discussing which portions of the board might be expendable. I highly recommend trying the variant island layouts, which can produce very challenging and interesting games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
An exciting little game that works well for beginners, yet is still a lot of fun for experienced gamers.  There is always a scary moment or two when you are turning over tiles, praying that you don't get more flooding.  It takes good cooperation and some clear headed decisions to win this one, along with a fair amount of luck.  It is a nice little mass market game with decent components and a low price.  It may not be quite as well done as Pandemic, but it is one of the cheapest thrills you will get at a game store.  This one should be in everybody's collection at one time or another.

RATING: 5
My first coop. I liked the theme of being stranded on this strange island, trying to find treasure and escaping alive. Unfortunately it was a little too simplistic. Often one or two players determined the 'optimal' plan, eliminating the decision making during individual turns.

In additon, the theme didn't came alive very well. Often it felt like Fobidden Island was more about draining the water then discovering the island and finding treasure. Was fun for a while but have no regrets selling this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Another stunning game from Matt Leacock (even if it is a scaled down and simplified Pandemic). Simple rules, simple mechanics but tons of gameplay and above all lots and lots of fun! We agreed that after 2 plays this is the only board game that has ever had us on the edge of our seats. Also this has to be the biggest bargain in boardgaming at the moment, I paid only £13.49 for a game which embarrasses the production of games that have cost me £35 and upwards. Love this game and will be playing it a whole lot more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great design, beautiful components and an affordable price! Its layout is very clear, and there's a real sense of panic when the island starts to sink. I felt it was easy, but there are several harder difficulties to which I'll definitely give a shot.
It's surprisingly similar to Pandemic, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I think this might be the best game to introduce games to people who normally pull faces at the mere mention of actually playing a game. It's simple to learn, it's cooperative so as to not frustrate people who don't like to lose (hi there!), and it can be played relatively quickly. Maybe half an hour in a group with at least one player to explain game play and help others as needed.

All in all, a great game with mechanics I've grown to appreciate (damn you, shuffle the discard and put on top of the draw pile!!).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[i]initial reaction[/i]
Being a big fan of Pandemic, I didn't rush to play this game, as I felt I would be disappointed given all the "pandemic light" comparisons I had heard... however when a copy turned up at a monthly church game group I go to, I suggested we give it a try... I played with my wife, and a couple of other ladies, one of whom is completely new to our "designer games". It actually went down very well... despite the simplified mechanisms from pandemic, there was still a great deal of tension, and we only just managed to make it off the island with the 4 treasures before it sank into the sea.
I'm still not convinced by the Tin... I'd much rather it came in a standard cardboard game box (so I won't be adding it to my collection just yet)... but I would certainly play it again. It worked pretty well as a gateway co-op game too.

[i]subsequently[/i]
Well I picked this up in the end, as we saw it at a discount in a book store while we were visiting the US. My wife likes it, but personally I would still rather play Pandemic.

RATING: 9
Great co-op game, gorgeous art. Feels like a real co-op where some cooperatives feel like they're just waiting to become competitive (which is fine! no arguments with that approach).

Simple enough I was able to teach it to my family in about 5 minutes, and good play time for a mix of ages all the way down to five. Younger players will love holding onto and playing with the treasure models.

Four years later: this is still getting plays about once a month. Fun to play, easy to teach, very pretty.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

This was a different kind of game play where everyone works together to beat the game so everyone is giving resources to each other and advice on which moves to make to make it off the island alive!  Very enjoyable.

RATING: 7.8
Fun little boardgame that can be enjoyed way below the recommended age range. My 5 year old son picked up the mchanics of this game after only 1 play and seems to enjoy it (he has asked to play it again). The only change I made to the mechanics was to remove the hand size limit of 5 cards. It's not that large of a change in my opinion, and I think it helped him grasp the other concepts quicker.

RATING: 6
Filler cooperative game that works pretty well, using the clever card mechanic from "Pandemic" to cause areas of the board to be repeatedly affected. But it is perhaps too simplistic, and the best choices are usually obvious. Beautiful artwork and very nice plastic treasures, but it is odd that the American version has dull generic pawns for the players, replaced with painted miniatures in the German edition.

RATING: 8

Christa et Nico
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As a family game this is not bad. I keep it because my child likes to play it with me, which is great. She would rate it an 8 or 9. This could be good for families looking for a very light cooperative game or those with younger kids. I do like the fact that it is short. I make my daughter take her own decisions and if she messes up not much is lost, and it is easy to start right back up without feeling that you have lost anything. It provides a good primer for deeper experiences. Not something I would play with my competitive gaming group.

Update: holding steady after a dozen plays. Still good for what I mentioned above but nothing more. 

Update: I am not sure why they didn't include the alternate island setups in the US manual (they were in the German), but they have made the game so much more interesting. The new setups are challenging and increase the replay value by 100 times. It is still below Forbidden Desert and Pandemic, but bumping up from 7 to 9 based on the alternate setups.

RATING: 5
Pandemic does a number of clever things to make you forget you're just hanging around waiting for the cards you need to cure something; Forbidden Island lacks these things. As such, you just hang around waiting for the cards you need.
That said, the sinking island mechanic is perhaps marginally better than Pandemic's cube spread--so there is something nifty. That, and the incredibly gorgeous components.

RATING: 7
A lighter and shorter Pandemic - IMHO, exactly what Pandemic needed, being condensed down to a shorter format that doesn't lose any core mechanics. There's no cube explosions in Forbidden Island, but it has everything else: Recurring floodings of the same tiles, increasing difficulty the longer the game progresses, individual player roles, and solution of the game by means of collaborative set collection and trading. Really neat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is a good buy for the price (I picked a copy up for a cool $15 and I've seen it as low as $11 in a grocery store... of all places). After multiple plays the game loses it's luster, however, and I only really play it nowadays with people that have never tried it. It's easy to learn and quick to play. I have also found myself fantasizing about rule deviations, to spice the game up. 

For example: The island is basically a 6x6 grid with the four corners missing. To add a bit of randomness to the game: (1) between each player's turn roll 2 six-sided dice, where one die represents rows and the other columns; (2) Find the island tile that is represented by the roll; (3) roll 2 six-sided dice again and locate the another tile; (4) SWAP the tiles. The island now becomes a mystical teleporting-tile island.

Addition (7/22/13): The shifting tiles idea I explain here is incorporated in Forbidden Desert. No, they probably did not get the idea after reading my review, but I swear I didn't know about this game until today. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Pretty much the same as forbidden desert but subtle changes.  Teh game is easy to learn for young kids but dont take it as a kid game only.  It does require the team work together but the rules are much simpler than many co-op.  And for that, I like it and its a great game for learning co-op games.  
I took this to a play with a group of young teens and watched them all scatter around the map, playing their own game, and quite efficiently dying.  Very enjoyable to watch the aftermath as they all placed the blame on each other.  If I were a manager of a fast-food joint this game would be part of my interview process.   
The game components are nice and well constructed.  The bits are attractive and overproduced for the simplicity of the game but makes finding them almost worth it wherein simple tokens might strain some of this joy.  The art is really good as well,

RATING: 8
Amazon price $11
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Wow! This is a really great game!

I mean, yeah, it's based off of Pandemic, so some folks say you don't need both; but I don't know about that. Though the mechanics are much alike, the experience is a lot different.

The smaller number of areas in play means a small Flood deck which turns over quickly, so every tile is going to be threatened; there are no safe spots, or areas that you can really afford to lose. if you let a few tiles go, the deck is smaller, and the tiles left are going to be threatened even more. The tension as parts of the island are flooded and fall into the sea is delicious!

Right at this moment, I'm prepared to say that I actually like Forbidden Island more than Pandemic! It plays quicker, and delivers as much cooperative fun as its big brother.

EDIT! Having played both some more, I'm prepared to say that I was full of it, here. Pandemic is definitely better. But FI is still a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Many reviews compare Forbidden Island and Forbidden Desert and crown "Desert" as the better game. While I do think "Desert" is more challenging overall, "Island" is a great game in its own right. The sinking dynamic with permanent land-loss is very different from the piling up of moving desert tiles; I think if you like one, you'll enjoy the other. And at their low price points, are worth purchasing. Great artwork; an easy co-op that is fun for those new to such gaming.

It`s a bit weird concept that if a part of the island is flooded, you can bring it back up as nothing have happened.

RATING: 7
I have gotten more into cooperative games as of late, and I found this one very enjoyable. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the best games as far as quality components and well thought out storage goes. The island cards are thick, sturdy cardboard stock and the plastic treasure tokens are a unique and wonderful touch. The tin has an organizer insert and everything has a place. I wish more game designers put as much thought into the game packaging as Gamewright did with this game!
I had a lot of fun playing the game, but eventually tired of it and gave it to my nephews. One nephew (5 at the time) understood it right away, but his older brother struggled a bit - depends on the kid, I guess. Regardless, I think this is a perfect game for kids (I'd estimate ages 9-11) and best suited to them. It seemed a tad juvenile and rote after a few plays with only adults.

RATING: 7
Matt Leacock has borrowed significantly from his Pandemic design (player special powers, cards replaced on top of the draw deck), but removed most of the character that made the original appealing. A short game by the standards of most co-ops, but fiendishly difficult to win, even on the novice level. Streamlining games seems to be a risky prospect (see Brass/Age of Industry for another example), this does nothing to improve my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b]ONE OF THE OLDEST TALES OF HOW MAN BRAVES THE ELEMENTS TO FIND SOME OLD TREASURES AND THEN RUN THE HELL OUT OF WHEREVER THE ELEMENTS MIGHT TRY AND KILL HIM AND HIS KIND[/b]

Without a doubt, one of the best games I have ever played. It has almost all the elements worth looking for in a game of this kind: Artistic value, good quality components, a smooth turn system, lots of strategy, a highly intelligent and unpredictable enemy, and very limited choices for the players once things start to crumble and fall. The only thing that it might be missing in this game is the possibility of winning alone, in case you’re actually the last one to survive. But that’s really not a necessity, since the game is already a masterpiece without it having to be like all other co-op games.

The game pits two to four players in an island that’s slowly starting to sink in the ocean. The players must find four different treasures, each representing one of the four classical elements, and each of them beautifully sculpted in resin or transparent plastic. For all things important in the game, from making sure everyone moves correctly and safely through the island tiles to getting the treasures safely from the receptive places, the characters count not only with cards that allow them to obtain the treasures, but also with their own particular ability.

As a consequence of the above mentioned things, a delicate strategy plan must be carefully planned before each turn, because the actions of each player can make thing easier for the others. Distance, movement, routes between point A and point B are also to be taken into account, since the unpredictability of the tiles sinking or disappearing beneath the waves is the danger everyone has to face. 

Mr. Leacock created an impressive co-operative game that focuses not on the action and suspense of the game and settings themselves, but on how the players react to each other and to their surroundings, making The Forbidden Island a completely new kind of game. Players have a shared goal, they must make sure the others survive and also, make sure the island doesn’t sink before they can get the treasures.

This game will definitely see a lot of gameplay in the future, and I don’t think it will ever stop being a top choice for me and my friends.

[b][i]I. Criteria[/b][/i]

Mechanics: :d10-1::d10-0:
Design & Art:  :d10-1::d10-0:
Packaging & Presentation: :d10-1::d10-0:
Theme: :d10-8:
BGG Factor: :d10-7:

[b][i]II. Sliders[/i][/b]

Abstract [b]_____[COLOR=#FF0000][6][/COLOR]____[/b] Themed: This game may very well be called “The Building on Fire”, but the them itself is not very interesting. I have heard that Mr. Leacock’s “Pandemic” is pretty much the same game, with a different them and a different level of tension and stress, with a few additions here and there. Theme for this game is not a very defining element, but it’s a lot more interesting t have the players flee an island sinking in the ocean than a trying to escape a building on fire or other like places or situations.

Simple [b]______[COLOR=#FF0000][7][/COLOR]___[/b] Complex: Strategic thinking, taking into account locations and probabilities, and combining those things with the randomness and unpredictability of the draw decks make The Forbidden Island a very complex game. Under no circumstances should it be seen as a filler or as a party game, or as a fast game for children. Every game will be different and despite the fact that players can be experienced “survivors”, the island is a lot smarter and faster..

Strategic [b]________[COLOR=#FF0000][9][/COLOR]_[/b] Tactical: The Island shifts with every turn, and positions may be lost or won. Strategies may be present and may last all the game, but this will never be strong enough or smart enough to make sure they carry out their purposes. Tactical thinking is a better path for players, at least in the most important areas of the game, for example, which players should get the treasures and which players should be those transporting people, cards or making sure the island stays afloat long enough for the players to reach the helicopter and flee. 
 
Luck [b]___[COLOR=#FF0000][4][/COLOR]______[/b] Skill: Despite the fact that everything about this game points to the players’ abilities and personal resolution of the players, the game is essentially a race against time, and against a board that is both highly intelligent and incredibly fast. Sometimes players will win the game with little to no effort, but sometimes, they won’t be that lucky .

Fiddly [b]________[COLOR=#FF0000][9][/COLOR]_[/b] Elegant: It took me and three other friends two game sessions with the rulebook opened to learn the “dos and don’ts” of the game, and how the island worked out against us. The rules are clear about how the cards work and the staggering lack of text in almost all cards is always a plus for a game that is meant to be played with a fast pace and without may nuisance and irrelevant matters. The rulebook, though short and small, is easily the most precise rule book I’ve read.
 
Indirect interaction [b]_________[COLOR=#FF0000][10][/COLOR][/b] Direct interaction: Team-work is an obvious necessity in the Island, because whatever ability one character has, it will affect the other one, so the players are meant to work together and make their specialties as effective as they can be.

Cutthroat [b]__________[/b] Friendly: As a cooperative game without a player taking the part of the bad guy (As in Middle-Earth Quest or Letters From Whitechapel), The Forbidden Island is not a game that could be seen as cutthroat or friendly, since the only possibility of winning the game results in the whole party surviving. Behaving like an idiot, trying to survive alone or just not helping the others or not listening to them when it’s important will result in this game not only being a complete failure, but also a burden and a poor choice when deciding what to play. It is recommended that this game should not be played with competitive players or people new to the gaming group..

Heavy use of language [b]_________[COLOR=#FF0000][10][/COLOR][/b] No language needed: Along the game, there are exactly three kind of cards that use text and watch one of them, after a few times of seeing them act, end up being just another card with symbols on them, so the players eventually never end up reading them. Sometimes, players may forget what they do exactly, but that’s almost never the case.

[b][i]III. Number of players recommended[/i][/b]: 4.

[b]CHEERS![/b]

RATING: 8
Brilliant game to play with children/family. It's like a simpler version of Pandemic which is makes it perfect as an intro to coops.

It's quickly become one of my daughter's favourite games so that's partly how I'm rating it. For gamers the decisions are a bit too simple so I'd go with Pandemic or another coop.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Forbidden Island, aka, Pandemic light. Coming from the same designer as Pandemic, you'll really get the same experience. But this is a much easier game. It's the coop I bring out if I'm teaching younger players a new game.

I really like the theme here. Explorers coming to a mysterious island, looking for four ancient artifacts of immense power. And as soon as they touch down...the island sense their presence and starts sinking! It's a race to shore up tiles that are sinking, saving one another, gathering the artifacts, and getting out TOGETHER! If one dies...you all loose.

The components in this game are phenomenal. Thick cardboard tiles that form the island. The Artifacts are actually sculpted and designed in such a way that it makes you want to get them. The different characters are just represented with pawns, so it would have been nice to have minis that looked like who they were supposed to be (i.e. Pilot, Diver, Engineer, Adventurer, ect.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my first board games that I tried that wasn't from the Hasbro family of my youth.  Forbidden Island really opened my eyes to how different board games could be.  It also helped me quickly pick up Pandemic, as well, since they both utilize mechanics from the same designer.  In that way, it also helped me start to identify authorial stamps from individual designers.

My wife and some friends who are turned off by more complex games seem to find this one appealing, yet I do too as a BG. I'm sure rating will increase with further plays, as the replayability for FI looks to be high.

One other note, when playing with the Diver, we replace Sunken tiles with glass beads so that it is more easy to recognize where he can use his special ability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
If you play with non-gamers and/or people who are turned off by the theme of Pandemic, Forbidden Island is worth looking at, especially at that price point. Forbidden Island has fewer special power cards in the draw deck, but I think it makes you work together more, and focus on each person's special powers. It is very similar to Pandemic, but has fun artwork and an approachable theme. One of the things that held me off from Pandemic for a while was the theme. If FI had been available, that would have been a GREAT game for us, and I think it will go over well with family groups and/or couples with a spouse who wants lighter gaming. The setup is pretty minimal, the rules are pretty minimal, but it does make for a challenge. It's quick enough that you can play again, which is always good to have it "sink in". I think, with the intended audience, it is a very good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Got the hang of it and am really enjoying it. Must get the cardboard version soon.

Got it, but waiting for birthday to roll around...

Finally got to play the cardboard version and am upping my rating. This game is a perfect match for my family. Theme is great for my young boys and gameplay is quick and easy. Co-ops are always a plus as it means no tears for the youngest after the game if he (we) loses. My wife loves the artwork, no complaints with the bits in this game. What a bargain!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fantastic cooperative game, perfect for families.  Even works well with 2 players, although this probably increases the difficulty somewhat as it is harder to keep shoring up tiles while the island is sinking and you only have access to 2 special abilities - which may limit your options.

Only possible improvement could be that the tiles actually do something, or infer some form of bonus/penalty for being on them.  I found that sometimes is was pointless to take any action as you were where you wanted to be, and nothing was forcing me to use my actions.  This didn't happen very often, however, and is a minor criticism.

Heartily recommended, especially for the low retail price it commands.  I was pleasantly surprised at how much interaction it took to beat the game, you will spend the whole game constantly discussing your tactics and the time will fly by.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This game, up to certain point, reminds me of Pandemic. Pandemic is more complex but, at some basic level, this can be considered a light version. It is a cooperative game where the players need to take every treasure on the island, for doing that, a certain number of cards of the specific color have to be played on the required location. Every player takes control of one character with unique abilities that, in combination with the rest of players, have to achieve the goal and leave the island before it is sunk under the sea.
It is a quick and fun game that works very well as a complement of a big strategic game. I do not play Forbidden Island as the main game of the afternoon.
Positive:
1. Easy to explain and play
2. It has a good level of difficulty
3. The box is comfortable to be transported
Negative:
1. There are some combination of characters that are doomed to fail
2. Like Pandemic, the round can be controlled by a "general" type of player that decides for the whole team what to do all the time
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Dan
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A nice game, solo possible as well. Good component quality and artwork. Another nice part is that the game puts itself up: when the tiles sink you toss them back in the box.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This might be my favorite game of all time. I've never found it easy to answer the question, "What's your favorite game?," because I like so many different types of games, but this one would have a good chance of coming out on top. When it comes to Co-ops, I believe Pandemic is amazing, but Forbidden Desert is just a little more fun for me. This sequel Forbidden Island is even better than Desert, and therefore the best Co-op game in my opinion. It removes the set collection mechanic of the game that makes Desert feel similar to Pandemic. The new Storm mechanic is amazing. It has a smooth game play that make the game easier to play, but harder to win. The only thing slightly worse about this game is the components. The pieces of the ship that you use to make the ship look great, but are flimsier. Also, the tiles on my game are starting warp slightly and are no longer sitting as flat as they once did. Those are both minor quibbles. This game is fantastic!

RATING: N/A
Forbidden Island is a blast. With artwork on par with Jamaica (another favorite), and simple addictive gameplay (not to mention nail-biting towards the end!), it's a must have. If you love co-op games, great artwork, and treasure hunting against the clock- BUY THIS GAME!

I traded out the normal pawns with my extra set of figures from 'The Adventurers"- what a difference the game makes. The pawns now match the artwork- as it should...My only real complaint with the game. 

UPDATE: Survive: Escape from Atlantis! has officially replaced Forbidden Island as the get off the island while you can game. No teamwork, just cutthroat right until the end. Replaced meeples with Lego Minifigures to add some much needed character to the game. Always a laugh to see the mime get eaten by the shark.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
My Sunday night group played three different times.  Since this was the first time playing Forbidden Island, we began at the very lowest water level.  We won all three times, but it was close to the skull and crossbones on two occasions.  

We thought the game played out well with the co-op.  It was difficult on the first round of play since we didn't really know what we were doing.  However, we played a turn or two, and the idea of the game fell into place.  After that, we just discussed what we needed to do win, provided we didn't get the Water Rises! card.

Overall, good game to play for a quiet evening.  It's not an overly intensive game that demands a lot out of an individual.  The major short comings was knowing how many cards are in the deck.  Once you know you have the Water Risings! out of the way, it's pretty smooth sailing.  However, I might have played the Treasure Cards wrong, so I will need to review it.

RATING: 7
As a fan of Pandemic, I avoided this game for a long time for fear it was too simple.  Having played it repeatedly on the iPad, I can say it is simpler, but not "too" simple.  The story arc is great (even compared to Pandemic, there is something exciting and satisfying about finally getting that fourth artifact and needing to get everyone back to the landing and onto the helicopter.  It would lose something compared to Pandemic, except that the huge variety of board configurations adds enough variety to keep it interesting.  It's not as tense and stressful as Pandemic, but still very fun.

RATING: 8.5

So much for a supposedly family friendly alternative to Global disease meltdown.

Good times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Don't get me wrong, this game isn't something I'd consider "not fun". This game is enjoyable for sure. Here's the thing though, we ended up playing Forbidden Island immediately after completing our first playthrough of Pandemic ... which as you may or may not know was ALSO created by Matt Leacock. Come to find out, it employs an EXTREMELY similar mechanic to Pandemic in its "Waters Rise!" card distribution (basically the exact same idea as the "Outbreak!" cards in Pandemic).

There's no real issue in that, but (as adult players) it felt a lot like a stripped down version of Pandemic -- something akin to more of a "children's version" of the same concept.

So there you go. If you've got Pandemic, stick with it. If you don't have either, grab Pandemic. If you've got kids, maybe Forbidden Island is a better choice. I dunno.

For us, we have decided that we will only pull out Forbidden Island if we are just way too intoxicated to make it through a round of Pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A challenging game with a great theme, it should be in everyone's collection simply based on cost. With a well oiled team machine you can win fairly easily, however, that isn't to say there is no challenge one wrong move or prediction and everything will go south.

RATING: 6
I owned it, but gave it to my friend who was moving out of city for fare-well gift. Hope this game serves her and her other loving half well :).

This one plays just like Pandemic - as a matter of fact, if you own Pandemic, you can safely skip this one and not miss a thing. Only two upsides Forbidden Island had over Pandemic were prettier arts, and simpler game play. Thus, if you are introducing a game to NBG friends, or young kids, this one is a great one to start out with. But after few plays, you will probably feel that you would want to look for something a bit heavier than this game. For this reason, I would actually try out Forbidden Desert instead of Forbidden Island.

RATING: 7
Quick, light, and fun.
Keeps many of the Pandemic mechanics in a stripped down, simple and quick coop. Probably the new standard for an entry level/gateway coop game - especially at $15.99 MSRP.

I agree with the "Pandemic for all ages" comment. Forbidden Island has a simpler game board, large "fun" pieces, more visually appealing, less "disconcerting"/serious theme, fewer actions per player turn, and fewer actions to choose from.

The only thing I would have changed is adding a stand-up for the water level card (which is a modification I'm making to my own set).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was my first intro to the cooperative game world, and if I had rated it then, I probably would've said 10 out of 10. It's a solid game, and it's a great one to pull out when I invite a non-gamer to one of our game nights. It's approachable and fun and a newbie will feel supported instead of attacked by experienced players. It actually has converted some newbie non-gamers I know into full on game geeks. Think of it as a "gateway drug."

Having said all that, I have since played Forbidden Desert and Pandemic (same designer) and I like them both a great deal more. Forbidden Island and Desert are actually extremely similar, but the few things that are different in Desert add so much depth and variation for replayability. Pandemic shares some similar mechanics in how the game attacks the players, but the player interaction and turn execution is very different, not to mention the thick list of cool expansions Pandemic has.

I want to say again, this is a good game, a fun game. The lower price point than those other two, and easier setup and explanation of this game for newbies does make it a great one to have in the collection. If you were only going to own one co-op game, I would choose one of the other two Matt Leacock designed, but I actually plan to own them all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Probably my favorite cooperative game to introduce to non-gamers. Simple game, but lots of suspense.

RATING: 8.5
I don't care what anyone else says, this is a delightful little game.  Easy to pick up and start playing right away.  Oh, but what a wonderful job at establishing a sense of dread and need to hurry, hurry, hurry.  But that's where the game gets you.  You need to think.  You need to plan.  You need to make sure that every step counts.  I am loving this game! I have been playing this game for a week now and my wife and I have won it once.  ONCE!  And that's because we were playing it wrong.  What does it feel like to me?  It feels like Indiana Jones, the board game.  You race.  You think.  You scavenge for treasure.  You co-operate.  What a fantastic game!

RATING: 7
Some similarity to Pandemic, this slicker version takes less time to play. The components are excellent and the design fits the theme very well.

Great to play with kids.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Forbidden Island is a calculated foray into the mass market. The game is patterned on designer Matt Leacock's previous game, Pandemic, which has enjoyed huge success within the confines of the boardgaming hobby. Though I wish Leacock success with a newer, potentially larger audience, Forbidden Island has nothing to offer me as a Pandemic fan. All of it's mechanisms are derived and diluted from the previous game, making it less interesting across the board and robbing it of any distinguishing features. In particular, the roles of the game are nearly equivalent in that they all amount to "conserve an action."  

Forbidden Island is an extremely inexpensive, nice-looking game. However, I question it's necessity as a "bridge" game. I can already get most people to play and enjoy Pandemic. 

Though in this case I can appreciate the goal, the trend of taking excellent, well-loved games and "streamlining" them continues to yield awful results. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
A very fun cooperative game. You are on an island that holds 4 treaures. During the course every turn after your 3 actions per turn you get 2 treasure cards. You must get 4 like treasure cards to go to the place that holds said treasures to collect said treasure. In the meanwhile the island is sinking all around you. Your job is to help each other out so you can all get off the island safely with the 4 treasures. Short, and fun with cool bits. I recommend it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Very similar to Pandemic (same author) but with streamlined rules. I actually like Forbidden Island better than Pandemic. It takes less footprint on the table, the map of the island is smaller, traveling around it is more straightforward between the tiles than along the lines of a complex map in Pandemic. Besides no more fiddly infection cubes on the board, just turn the tile on its back to make it flooded or take it away from the map to make it gone under water forever. Overall I recommend it to anyone considering buying Pandemic - try this one instead - it’s pretty much the same thing, only less confusing to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
In a parallel universe where this predated Pandemic I might well have given it another point, complimenting the clever "it puts the cards on the deck" mechanism. In this world, there's nothing here that doesn't feel like a repeat with pretty much every aspect reduced in complexity and dressed in a less disturbing theme for family appeal. The topography is simplified, local threat levels are binary and isolated. It doesn't feel like you have many nonobvious choices, or much chance of success once the negative feedback loop gets going. And with the cards all open by decree, there's really no reason why there should be more than one person making decisions.

RATING: 9
Family game - cooperative

pros
- mechanics of the game: awesome, makes the game really tense
- illustrations are fantastic
- always exciting gameplay
- you can calibrate the level of difficulty
- the island is always different from the previous games
- different roles for the players
- quick, there is always time for a second try...
- easy upgrade to FD or Pandemic

cons
- we are a family of five, and this game supports 4 players...

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I've only played this game 3 or 4 times, with children and with adults, but I'm not keen to play it again.

Its central mechanics of steadily increasing threat, and calamity repeatedly hitting the same places, are identical to Pandemic. The theme of collecting cards, too, and taking them to some specified location. The idea of collecting stuff reflects the cured disease. So in a sense, this is a kind of Pandemic reskin, but I don't think it works.

Pandemic builds tension about whether you can win the game, and the alternative possible actions for the various characters leads to interesting discussion and clever strategies. In Forbidden Island, the alternatives are never really distinct enough to discuss, and as for winning or losing, I have never been able to care.

RATING: N/A
GWHWY6 $1.39
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Acquired Nov.2012
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I prefer pandemic, but with some groups I definitely prefer this. It really lit a fire with my son around the time he turned 6. He had shown some interest in games before (Kids of Carcassonne; Duck, Duck, Bruce; Spot it). Forbidden Island produced a kind of zeal and focus I had not seen before. This is the first time I did not need to suggest a game: he got it off the shelf himself and began setting it up. Just one play was enough to fascinate him and after two plays he wanted to draw his own cards and name new parts of the island.

The game is often described as pandemic light. It's better described as Pandemic for families. I understand that is what Gamewright asked Leacock to do. That is, to take the pandemic system, streamline, and make it more accessible to younger children. He delivers on that in spades.

It is easy to teach, easy to learn, and plays quickly. It works well with a range of ages. It's a pleasant experience, with less tension and complexity than Pandemic, but still tense. One of the great family games. 

I would rate this for me, and my tastes, about a 4 or 5. Given the choice I'd rather play something else. But when I consider the design and the target audience, this game is at least an 8. Everything about this game is excellent: the design, the gameplay, the production. And the price is amazing too. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I didn't like Pandemic much, but I like 'Forbidden Island'.  It is very well designed to keep you constantly feeling endangered but not actually killing you off as soon as you feared!  It's pretty light, though.

RATING: 7
Family members really loved this game during our Christmas get-together. It was continually requested. I personally don't mind it but don't enjoy it as much as they did. 

It is a cooperative game which means you need to watch out for bossier or louder individuals taking control of gameplay by dictating everyone's moves. We had a few situations where quieter players felt they didn't get to have a say. They complained that the game was worthless if they just moved their pieces in the way that others dictated. Had to monitor everyone's input after that to make sure the game was truly cooperative.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game was the first designer boardgame I bought, mostly because of how cheap it is. I like the cooperative aspect and I like that it's fairly easy to learn. Despite being easy to learn it's a fairly hard game. I've played about 6 games and only won once and it was because we were failing to discard the land cards when the tile was removed from the board.

There's a lot of strategy that goes into this and I like that every game is different due to the randomized map. I'd say it's a bit unbalanced though, it's very hard to beat without the engineer in my experience.

I really like this game though, I wish my friends liked it more!

Edit: By the way the quality of the game is much higher than I expected for $16 which I paid for it. The value is excellent.

RATING: 10
A surprisingly fun Matt Leacock game!  I didn't expect too much from this having already played Pandemic and Forbidden Desert which were basically successors to the cooperative engine developed in Forbidden Island.  But I really liked it a lot!  Maybe even more than Forbidden Desert which is an all time favorite of mine.  It has a similar feel to Forbidden Desert but my biggest complaint about Desert is constantly having to put out all the fiddly desert cards.  There is none of that with Island which makes it easier and more suitable for nights when I'm feeling like a simpler game.

RATING: 7
This is a very nice cooperative family game built on the same basic chasis as Pandemic.  But the differences between the two games are still pretty significant, making it well worth the incredibly low price to buy this as well.  The "sinking" mechanic of the island is really cool and adds a lot to the experience, and the differences in how the decks are constructed make for a nice twist as well.  If you're into coops and have a need for a family game or light (20-30min) filler, then this is WELL worth it.

RATING: 7
I bought this game from Kohl's for around $40 something (Target sold it for way cheaper: $17.99). I have played Forbidden Island with my friends afterschool and my brother. So far I have played it around 5 times or more. This game is a very fun cooperative game. We always discuss the moves we want to make and what is essential to help us win. The roles are pretty cool too and give you nice abilities. This game does get boring though. If you play it to often in a row, you might need a long break. I found this game to be pretty unpredictable, which adds to the fun/ Overall, it is something I enjoy playing just not to often. I plan on getting a similar game called Forbbidden Dessert very soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I LOVE any game that plays differently each time, plus, it's a nice change of place from competitive to cooperative. In this case, the game tiles always lay out differently every time, and your roles always change, so replay value is high.

It gets a higher score, because it's HARD. You really need to make as few mistakes as possible to win, so the incentive to play is always high, because you WANT to beat the game, knowing you've tasted plenty of defeat in the past...

Yes. I copied and pasted. They are that similar of games. I give Desert the slight edge because of it's steampunk-esque art direction, and the Indiana Jones discovering a lost city in the desert feel. Mechanics differ slightly, and I think I prefer excavating game tiles and finding things, over keeping the island afloat, as you do in Forbidden Island...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Gave to Claire (& Nick's family); will move on to Forbidden Desert

RATING: 5
Forbidden Island is a fairly simple game, the kind you'd enjoy playing with your 10-year-old niece or nephew.  Since it's cooperative, there's no competition among the players.  Everyone wins or loses together.  Luck is a minor though unavoidable component of the game, and the mechanics allow for a highly adjustable difficulty level.  This isn't a strong favorite of mine, but it's a good pick if you want to include a cooperative game that appeals to a wide range of ages.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We enjoy [thing=30549][/thing], so we were curious how this would play  and it was cheap enough that picking it up was an easy decision. The components are really good, although the cards were fairly warped. The artwork and theme is a lot more colorful and approachable than Pandemic as well. In terms of gameplay, while the mechanics and actions are taken from Pandemic, the game does feel different. You start with a new map each game.  You no longer have outbreak chain reactions. Instead, different parts of the map itself start sinking.  This should give more variety to the game.

However, we didn't really feel any tension---the easiest thing would be to increase the difficulty, which we did do later. But even if there were a couple of map tiles out of the way that were flooded, we didn't feel any need to go way out of our way to shore them up. Pandemic felt much more thematic in that respect---you're treating the diseases in different cities, which also has the side effect of reducing outbreaks and so forth. In Forbidden Island, thematically we didn't see a need to shore up those far flung map tiles, especially if they weren't important (i.e., not treasure tiles or Fool's Landing). The only reason is for a gameplay mechanism---you need to keep the flood deck more diluted so as to not flood the important areas. It felt more puzzle-like and less intense for that reason.

We definitely prefer Pandemic by a large margin. I've taught it to many non-gamers, so I don't feel a need to get an even more approachable version.  We also tend to prefer these type of coop games with more than just two anyway, as that adds to the cooperative, working-togeher feeling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

Pre Dec 11 

What has not been said already, a great family co-operative game for those who fear drowning more than dying from an infectious disease.

We play with a wide range of age groups so have the water levels firmly starting at 2 however look forward to increasing it a bit soon and raising the challenge.  I have no worries though as we are British and it is in our genetic make-up to steal treasures from foreign lands with no thought to the environment or local habitats.

RATING: 6.5
[microbadge=5792]

It takes about two minutes to learn (less if you know Pandemic) and is simple to strategize (simpler if you know Pandemic).  The theme isn't as compelling, nor the board as difficult.  However, it makes a nice gateway gift if you're into that sort of thing.

RATING: 7
I'm not the biggest fan of co-ops but this is such good value. Great quality and a decent little game that I can play with the kids. I do quite like the puzzle quality of it, something I'd admired in my solo play, but there is that little niggle that if the next card had been something else we could have won and it is so arbitrary that we did not. You might say that perhaps you should not be in such a situation but the clever thing in this game is that the increasing pace of sinking ups the tempo and puts you in that kind of situation, like it or not. In short, I'm glad I have it and will play with upon request (especially with the kids) but it did show us that co-ops aren't really our thing and so we don't need to own any more.

RATING: 8
This is a quick, pleasant game with a charming backstory. It doesn't have a great deal of strategic depth, but manages to generate a lot of suspense in a short time, I think it's probably THE very best 'gateway" game on the Geek for gently introducing hapless Hasbro/Milton Bradley victims to the idiosyncratic charms of Euro-style gaming. In spite of being pretty easy to learn, it manages to incorporate many of the most distinctive mechanics from that genre: co-op play, one-per-player rules exceptions, and game turns that consist of choosing from a menu of possible actions. Also, the art and the plastic bling are absolutely gorgeous & worthy of sustained contemplation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A solid family weight cooperative game with simple mechanics.  You are trying to get treasure off an island before it sinks.  You work together to collects sets of cards and travel to the spot with where you get the treasure.  Once you have the treasure you travel back to Fools Landing and play a helicopter card to leave.  Each player has different abilities and the game will eliminate a lot of tiles quickly.  You must share cards to win.  

Very fun and a great family weight game.

However, the art is beautiful, and it's a very good primer for people new to gaming, especially if you plan to introduce them to Pandemic eventually.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
This is essentially a "lite" version of Pandemic. Pandemic is a game that I wanted to like, but after several plays, and checking and re-checking the rulebook, I still can't win, and I find it unforgivingly difficult. Not so with Forbidden Island, which seems quite winnable.

Unfortunately, it seems that in the end, the starting difficulty really just determines a probability of success. The game is not an intelligent opponent, and so, just like with Pandemic, there are really no surprises. Without the rich theme of a game like Arkham Horror, this is all just a bit dull. I sometimes wonder if the success of co-op games has more to do with the fact that many geeks struggle to find gaming partners than it does with anything inherently interesting about coop games.

RATING: 6
======== Skill Floor Level: 3 out of 9
======== Approachability Grade: A

You're an archaeological team sent to investigate a rumor of a long-dead but advanced island civilization, and to recover artifacts which allegedly control the four classical elements. You arrive at the island but trip its defensive measures, causing the island to start to permanently sink into the ocean. Your team must quickly gather all four artifacts and reach the helicopter pad to escape.

RATING: 7
It's more about having fun than a thoughtful strategy, a game session runs quick and smooth but with a nice dose of adrenaline (the island is sinking!). My only observation is that at the begining of a game it seems like you are only making random moves while you end your turn to obtain treasure cards, thankfully that sensation doesn't last too long as the game gain momentum through the dissapearing tiles.

IMHO is a nice introductory game to non gamers, and propably will work great with the youngest of the family.

BTW the art and general production of the game is awesome.

Update: you got to play it with the non-standard island setups, It is way more fun than the default setup

RATING: 7
Light co-op for 2-4 players, also know as Pandemic-lite. Players move around the flooding island, shoring it up while they collect 4 clues to each of 4 treasures. Once they're got all 4 treasures they have to get away in the helicopter. Fun theme and nice execution. Have fan expansion with tile layouts, additional roles, traitor.

RATING: 7.9
Nice game, especially if you're looking for something that lasts no more than 45 minutes, is cheap or can accomodate children (I'd say they can enjoy it from 8yo, but that's a guess).

My only gripe is that it IS really a Pandemic light. There is almost nothing new here to people that already own Matt Leacock's other fantastic game. No new mecanism, and the feel of play is exactly the same, except for the theme. So, for the (admittedly small) amount of money I gave for this, I'd rather have had something really new. So the only people I wouldn't recommend it to are those who already have its big brother and aren't bothered by its reasonable play time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
To quote my wife, "With Pandemic, I feel like I'm trying to win.  With Forbidden Island, I feel like I'm trying not to lose."

While Forbidden Island is mechanically a simpler version of Pandemic, it manages more tension in a much shorter time.  For that reason, I actually prefer this over its big brother.  But it does suffer from the possibility of a first turn loss, so I knocked it down a point from 8 to 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It sounds like Pandemic Lite, but after reading about it I expected something a bit different -- it actually is Pandemic Lite. More family friendly, faster (the biggest difference), and less prone to railroading newer players -- all good things. The components are great; the tiles are pretty, and the treasures are exceptional. It will be easier to introduce to new gamers, and more fun for the casual gamers in our extended circle.

On the flipside, it's much less interesting than Pandemic. It's still tense, but the optimal course of action is almost always clear on every turn. The randomness of the Waters Rise card distribution introduces some tension in a new way, but even that can be accounted for.

---

I haven't wanted to play this in three years, it's time for it to go. Re-rated from a 7 to a 6 and sold.

RATING: 8
The fact that Matt Leacock managed to make a game with slightly easier rules than his previous masterpiece Pandemic but with just as much excitement astounds me. If anything, the slightly easier rules make me more eager to teach it to my potential real life gaming partners than with Pandemic, and with more plays, I predict this will become a 9.

My only issue is that the rules aren't as precise regarding certain things as in Pandemic, requiring more use of BoardGameGeek to learn the finer details (such as how precisely the Diver works, or how the Navigator interacts with the Pilot and Diver). Thankfully, Matt Leacock is very generous with explanations on the forums!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Одна из первых наших игр, всем нравится.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Forbidden Island is a light co-op game in which players are explorers trying to find four treasures and leave the island before it sinks into the sea.  The entire island is a grid of tiles that will start on their face up coloured side, eventually flip to their monochromatic blue side as that part of the island floods, and eventually be removed from the game altogether as it is lost to the sea.

Players start with a character card which lets them know what their special ability is.  Then when it's your turn you can do three actions which are any combination of: move, shore up (which means turning a blue flooded tile back to its coloured side), give a card to someone else, or turn in a set of cards to find/take the matching treasure.  The next thing they'll do is take two treasure cards from the treasure deck.  These will either be helpful cards that will go toward them finding the treasures, because when you have four of the same type of treasure card you can go to the appropriate tile, trade them in, and get the treasure.  Or, they may be detrimental "waters rise" cards which will go a long way toward making the players lose.  The last thing players do on their turn is flip over the number of flood cards equal to the current waters rise level.  These cards match the tiles on the island and you flip, or remove tiles matching the flood cards you draw.

Players win together if they all survive, get all four treasures, and escape the island.  If they miss any of these criteria they lose.

I like Forbidden Island.  It's an easy game to understand and play, but not necessarily an easy game to win.  The components are top notch, especially the four treasures which are nicely rendered out of plastic.  This would be a good one to play with new gamers, kids, or when you don't want to play for very long.  I definitely recommend it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sold

RATING: 9
Best game of 2010.
Awesome lighter co-op. Some days I even prefer it to Pandemic because it's 2x faster. It's action point co-op boiled down to its basics, leaving just enough space for theme, and why wouldn't that recipe work. Unlike some say, it's not too easy if you use proper difficulty level, you can't 'solve' random game. Alternate setups found on BGG are must after 10 games or so though, to keep it fresh. Great components for the price.

2-Player Comment: 
*Co-op, no problems with two. Good 2p game.

RATING: N/A
Played this on 13/8/2010 for the first time with a group of Year 5 students at school (10-11 yr olds). It was a huge hit, they wanted to play it again straight away - meanwhile we had a cluster of children around us who wanted to know what the new game was. Even a first teaching game took only around 45 minutes, making it fit well into our games program.
The resemblance to Pandemic is clear but this is a good game in its own right. It seems much easier, perhaps because players can take a strategic approach to letting tiles be eliminated from the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
If you have Pandemic, don't bother with Forbidden Island. Pandemic is way better for those looking for a good game. The mechanics are so similar for both, that they don't seem like seperate games... Forbidden Island = Pandemic "lite". Forbidden Island is more approachable to non-gamers and takes less time to play, with fewer rules than Pandemic. I'd suggest Forbidden Island as a gateway game for non-gamers new to the hobby, or as a training tool for Pandemic to get people used to a cooperative game with variable player powers and the need to "put out fires" while making progress towards winning the game. My wife and I have played Forbidden Island a few times and were left unimpressed. We love Pandemic and felt Forbidden Island was a step down on the fun factor. Like I said, Forbidden Island would be a better (i.e. more approachable) game for younger or newer players, but is not different enough from Pandemic to count it as a seperate game, and is not nearly as fun to play or challenging/rewarding to play as Pandemic.

*update: for a this game has been replaced by pandemic: the cure as our intro to coop games and a great "Pandemic 101" course to build up to the fully immersive Pandemic experience.

RATING: 7
Until now I haven't liked co-ops, I'm more the competitive kind of gamer. Anyhow I'm looking forward to try a lot of good ranked games in this category. Forbidden Island, even though isn't fun for me, is a very good game to play with children, family or casual gamers. High production value, this game is simply beautiful. 

After another play I'm happy that I gave my copy of Forbidden Island to my brother so I can still play it, this is a gorgeous game and a hard one if you increase the water level, 2 games in a row last time, amazing agonic fun! Up to 7: Good Coop suitable for the family, short enough to serve as a filler.

RATING: 7
Fun co-op game for the whole family. Simple rules, beautiful artwork and components, some thinking required but not enough to get a headache.  Difficulty can be tailored to the appropriate level for the players on hand, and board setup is different every game.  This is THE gateway co-op game for non-gamers as far as I'm concerned.  It also helps that the game is incredibly cheap at $13 or so.

Component quality is amazing.  Tile art is beautiful and the treasure pieces are very nice.  My kids want to play with the treasure pieces more than they want to play the game.

RATING: 7
I really like this game - 2 player is the most fun. It is not the deepest game and yes, the choices are obvious. However the theme works so well and the game plays so quickly that it really feels like you are racing to escape a sinking island. The beautiful components, quick set up, ease of explanation, quick play time, and thematic experience really make this little gem shine. This is my first taste of a co-op game and I really enjoyed it. The game is also really tough to beat, making it even more fun, IMO. However, it is what it is. If you are looking for a complex and strategic main event, this is not it.

RATING: 6
A fun game for sure.  Nice mechanics and fast paced.   It does leave me wishing for a little more meat though, as the best moves tend to be pretty obvious.  At the hardest difficulty level, the game realy boils down to the order you draw your cards.  You'll either hit the highest flood level or get the last card you need to win.  Kind of a random ending to an otherwise fine game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
First Impressions: Beautifully made game with a really fun mechanic. The co-operative aspect is a nice change of pace from every other game I own, and especially some of the screw-your-friend styles.
Played with 2 players. On the easier levels, the game just doesn't seem to be that difficult. There never seemed to be any real risk of losing. Forbidden Island is fast and fun, with our first games lasting around the 20-30 minute mark. Great value for the low pricepoint.

Updated Impressions: On the 3rd and 4th plays the next day, we upped the starting water level difficulty and felt the urgency a little more. With random board layout, the game sometimes gives you an easy play through, while other times creating more of a challenge. This will remain a fun filler game when we want to play something quick and easy after dinner or on a rainy afternoon, or serve as a bridge game to introduce new games.

Possible 2 Player Variation: I thought it would increase the tension if each of the two players had 2 or 3 Adventurer cards. On each turn, the player would rotate to the next Adventurer role in their hand and only use those advantages for that turn. This would ensure that the Helicopter Pilot can only bounce around and save the day once every 4 or 6 turns.  



NB: I have never played Pandemic, but it seems to be law here on BGG that any review of Forbidden Island compare it to Pandemic.

RATING: 6.5
co-op game.  Try to gain possession of 4 artifacts before the island sinks around you.  Its quick to play and offers good tension in how to approach things.

Positives:
+ nice components for easy play
+ lots of different roles to choose from adds to replayability
+ variable island shape adds replayability
+ easy to understand game play 
+ little down time between turns
+ fairly easy to adopt for solo play

Cons:
- sometimes feels a little too simple (actions seemed obvious in the first two games played)
- sometimes hard to find specific tiles as graphics can sometimes be too close to each other

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: Players work together to collect four treasures off a sinking island and fly away before being sucked into the ocean’s abyss.

Played as: 2,3,4 player

Pros: The first thing that stands out is the amount of quality game that is packed into such a reasonably priced package. Really, it’s a steal, from component quality to gameplay.  Not too difficult of a game from a rules standpoint, but still offers a brutally challenging goal and great sense of tension.  Definitely has that snowball feeling as the game progresses, as things start deteriorating faster and faster, all leading up to generally close, pressure-filled ending. The game seems to scale very well, both in players and difficulty, and the number of different roles seems to be at a level that should keep things fresher for longer.

Cons: After a few plays, I’m sure the chance of success is going to have more to do with luck then skill once players figure the game out.  Doesn’t do a whole lot better then its bigger brother Pandemic.

Other: Just a note on this game compared to Pandemic-- They are both still very familiar in flow, but I think Forbidden Island presents some new challenges not seen in Pandemic that will force veterans of the later to think in new ways or face multiple deaths. Do you need to own them both? Maybe, maybe not. If Forbidden Island wasn’t so stinking cheap, I’d lean towards no; but it is cheap, so maybe. If I were to only own one, I’d stick with Pandemic; but one thing I haven’t mentioned is what FI is intended for and that’s a younger audience. I’ve only played with adults so that’s one dynamic I can’t comment on. 

Best Use: The quickest Co-op out there that’s plenty accessible for a range of players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
It's a good co-op that's easy to play, but challenging to win. I think I prefer the outbreak mechanics that make Pandemic such a thrilling game, but this one is probably much more accessible to a general audience. I might pick this one up one day, but it's just too close to its big brother.

Update: Although I did get a copy if this and enjoyed it many times, my rating has gone down because it just doesn't have the depth of Pandemic and many other co-op games and I'm a bit bored with the game. I would still gladly play the game with others to introduce them to this style of game and highly recommend the game to anyone.

RATING: 5
Too similar to Forbidden Desert. The artwork and theme is more interesting in Forbidden Island though, and I like the fact that the tiles do not contain hidden information because the tiles in Forbidden Desert get damaged really easily.

Hand limit of 5 makes this feel really gamey because of forced discards almost every turn. Decision-making is very simple as well.

RATING: 6.5
This is supposed to be Pandemic light.  The feel (hopeful alternating with stumbling anxiety) is about the same.  The playing time is about the same as Pandemic, at least in my family.  Although arguably FI is easier to win, it seems to me that it is possible to lose very quickly without having much say in the matter.  Things can turn south quickly in Pandemic as well, but usually you have a few turns breathing space at the start.  

I like that you can use the tile layout to vary the difficulty level of the game.  Some of the "official" layouts look very grim!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Also even when we don't win my kids seem to enjoy the fact that the island sunk and we were all lost at sea!

RATING: 6
It's an okay light game--Pandemic Lite, to be specific--that has the sole advantage of being quicker and easier. It would be a '5' but for the fact that you can probably get this to the table more easily with a reluctant crowd. It's okay, but I'd rather play Pandemic.

It does have nice artwork, especially on the tiles. The insert is well-designed. The box is attractive. The theme is light but well-chosen. The length is perfect for what it is. And you can easily play it solo. Despite its limitations, there's a lot to like.

RATING: 9
We've played this numerous times in large groups and two-player co-ops. This is a great game where "the island is trying to kill you!" Movements, actions and strategy are completely cooperative - and engaging. Everyone has their special skill that they can employ to help the team. With careful coordination and skill - it's possible to find a solution and path to victory. The mechanism is pretty solid with various degrees in how to make the game tougher. That alone can help make the island more challenging as we try to save the artifacts and fly off the island successfully. 

We're a big fan of co-op games and Forbidden Island did not disappoint!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[microbadge=1714]  [microbadge=21390]

[u]16-Jan-2013[/u]:  In terms of dollars-to-fun quotient, this may be the best game I own.  It's a "lite" version of Pandemic, where you take on the roles of adventurers trying to escape a sinking island with four found treasures.  I love this game for its artwork, components, simple rules, and family friendly fun.  I even enjoy playing this gamy by myself.  The theme is stronger here than in Pandemic, I believe, because of the aesthetics of the game...lots of nice pictures on the tiles and the large plastic treasure figurines are great.  And all of this for like fifteen bucks (USD)!  And easy recommend for family gamers.  You can even check out the forums for additional island set ups for lots of variety and even more challenge.

[u]24-Jan-2014[/u]:  I know this one hasn't hit the table in several months, but it remains one of my favorite games.  It's a light, not-too-thinky, and fun co-op experience...solo and multiplayer.  With the additional island layouts that can be found in the forums, you've got that much more fun packed into this small, inexpensive tin of a box.  I still feel this is the best game I have in relation to my gaming dollar spent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
[I'm essentially pasting the same review here that I used for Forbidden Desert]

This and Forbidden Desert were important gateway games for our family and so they will always have a special place in our hearts. Island is less complex and a little easier than Desert, but both are games we've been able to play with our girls for a few years (they are 9 and 12 now)--though they can sometimes prove taxing for them if they are not in the mood. 

My wife and I, however, also play two players and really enjoy it. In fact, we will play multiple characters, throw in some house rules, and just have fun. I'm excited to get my "game board" I found on Etsy to help keep the tiles in place and class up the joint. 

Ultimately, we love co-op games, and this is a good one that is a great gateway to more complex games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Well done little game.  Great artwork.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Easy mechanics of rules not very thematic. Both equate to easy pick-up for non die-hard gamers.

Nice packaging (metal box), miniatures (4 treasures), tile island pieces and cards with nice pics. Good quality production although the characters can be nicer if provided as miniatures instead of colored cones.

As mentioned, gameplay is easy to pick up, fast pace (normal game finishes in about 30 mins) and co-op. Objective is to get all 4 treasures and escape the island alive. 

An element of randomness in terms of drawing the flood cards though but this somehow adds to a certain degree of predictability in the game midway through in terms of the probability of win versus losing. However, replayability is pretty good although it isn't that challenging after a few plays.

I played on Christmas eve with my nephew, niece and sis. We won 2 and lost 1. Mid-way through the game, we are already aware of what is the most likely results and it seem really hard to reverse it. Possibly, there are games played by others whereby it isn't so predictable but those I played isn't so.

Here's my rating:
Aesthetics: 7/10
Gameplay: 13/20
Replayability: 6.5/10

[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* One of the granddaddies of the co-op genre
* Scales well with any number of players, but more is always better
* Unique powers of roles make for interesting strategy each game
* Removal of tiles as the game progresses makes for great tension throughout
* Good for family gaming and co-op fans
* Initial rating: [b]7/10[/b]

RATING: 7
Really good cooperative game! The theme of the sinking island is nicely rendered and you do need to work with the others players. The more players, the more challenging the is!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Co-operative game themed around explorers collecting treasure from a rapidly sinking island. Players negotiate their way round a randomly generated island made up of 24 tiles collecting cards which ultimately can be cashed in for a specific treasure. As play progresses the tiles become flooded and then ultimately sink below the sea, making it a race against time to collect all four treasures and make it to the helicopter pad and off the island. A nice filler game which takes no more than half an hour to play. Will be enjoyed by children of all ages; all cards are face-up so you can help younger children to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's an excellent game for what it is - a lighter, simpler Pandemic. The movement is simpler, and the game still has unique roles and a few event cards. The artwork on the tiles and cards is gorgeous. It's a nice entry-level/family game.

Indifferent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Quite accurately described as 'Pandemic Light', Forbidden Island is a cooperative survival game in which players work together to card handle and threat assess the sinking island whilst rescuing treasure and making their escape.

Its simple and easy enough to teach, and plays very quickly. It works as a great filler, and is an excellent gateway game. Its non-gamer difficulty means it will be immediately playable to almost anyone, and it is widely available even in mainstream retailers such as Waterstones and The Works.

I personally much prefer its follow up game [thing=136063][/thing].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.9
Good entry level co-op game. The rules are really simple and difficulty scales quite well even for more hardcore players. This is a game you could even play with children or your familily but the only problem is that it is too easy for one player to "solve" the game on it's own. To have fun you have to give opportiny to your playmates to make some decisions (which are sometimes wrong) by themselves.

For me, the game became boring quite quickly and I probably won't play this in serious gaming groups no longer. But with my family it's a fine game.

RATING: N/A
location: home (medium)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Video Review: https://youtu.be/rpA2E7sd670

Forbidden Island is a simpler, earlier implementation of Pandemic. If you have the sequel Forbidden desert or Pandemic the only reason you might want this is the younger family friendly nature of it or if you enjoy the theme. That's not to say it's not an enjoyable game, but a pass for me due to pandemic being in my collection.

The game itself is played on a sinking island made up of tiles, on your turn you are trying to shore up the island while collecting treasure and helping others. It's a lot of fun but can sometimes end very quickly with bad luck in the card draws!

RATING: 6
This game is a kid friendly version of Pandemic. While the game mechanics are very similar between Forbidden Island and Pandemic, the two games with accompanying themes are different enough to make owning both well worth it. Forbidden Island is a little lighter, but can be equally challenging. The theme appeals to kids and adults alike. For the price, it's hard to find a better value game than this. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pandemic-lite.
Nobody seems to like this too after a few plays.
Might consider trading or selling this off soon.

RATING: 6
Simple and elegant co-op game that is both easy to teach and generally proves to be tense near the ending.  After enough play throughs it becomes a bit too repetitive, so keeping your play throughs limited to a few times per month or more helps keep the game fresh.  There is a means to increase the difficulty by increasing the water level.  However, I found that it poorly increases the difficulty by making it go from a some what challenging experience to impossible win.  Over all a great game that is a must own!  Plus, the pieces are super well make, hardy, and well designed.  I think this game cost me $16!  Worth every penny!  For a more difficult experience, try Forbidden Desert!

RATING: 7

We started at the easy level and worked our way up, most of the time we ended up with a mostly complete island. When we finally put it to the hardest difficulty we finally started to have a challenge, but that still isn't saying much. It felt like we only lost because of bad luck. Our fist card was Fool's Landing, the next was Water's Rise, and we lost: in one turn. Still, I enjoy the co-op play, and we still have fun trying to solve a new puzzle every time.
