RATING: 8
Can't get over how pretty the tiles are, the gameplay is superb, fast and simplistic but always very tense.  Great family friendly coop.

UPDATE: 01/01/14

Okay, this is kind of a cheat too because I haven’t played much of the actual board game in ages.  However, it deserves a mention because I have played loads of games of it on the iPad because it plays so quickly.  I probably wouldn't break it out in ‘real life’ unless I'm introducing new players/kids – it made a great present for my 8 and 9 year old nephews for example.  I love the simplicity of the game and the theme, the artwork is absolutely beautiful, and I just think it’s really a perfect little game.  I don’t know why the Forbidden Desert theme doesn’t really do anything for me, I guess it doesn’t seem as exotic or interesting somehow – if they were movies I’d be more interested in seeing Forbidden Island than Forbidden Desert.  I guess I should give Desert a go sometime.  Maybe it’ll make another nice present for my now 9 and 10 year old nephews…  But yes, Forbidden Island will remain in the collection as a gateway game should the need ever arise to introduce somebody to gaming this way.  If it comes to game night though, I’d much rather play and get my teeth into something meatier.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ironically, I prefer this solo over co op.  I dislike holding back in co op to stop my alpha gaming. I also dislike a little bit of the maintenance and order, but its simplicity and speed is nice. I also love the theme, components, artwork, and streamlined play in 30 min

Played mire and surprisingly enjoy this a lot more than any other co op Ive played. Its relaxed, light, fast fun. Theres replay in different role combinations and map tile setups. With a decent or good group, its fun and ends faster than Pandemic with arguably same level of luck. Not same level of decision making but easier for beginners to understand and better theme.

I also like how modular it is with official variant board layouts and treasure ideas. Will print when I get the chance to avoid the game getting samey.

I like the game quite a bit but have recently found Legendary very feasible to beat, even with some alternate maps. I still like this more than other co ops, but I wanted something more - some story/additional challenge/thought/abilities for every tile. I still prefer the art but have gotten a bit too used to it, so its impact has worn off. I like that its not as fiddly as other co ops and its probably my fave co op still, but I'd rather play a competitive game atm still.

I guess cooperatives truly aren't for me.

After playing this more, I still think this is probably my favorite co op at the moment, but I am a little tired of it. Its rather simple and easy to win and the variant layout doesnt add that much replay since its the same actions. I think I need a bit more thinkiness and not as much obvious plays which this occasionally has. I also wish more tiles could do more things and it could be a bit less finicky. I guess co ops arent for me. I also feel like its not an exciting that many request over and over and typically have average sessions of it. Also, for gateways, I guess I can use other games like Splendor or so. Trading.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very nicely balanced cooperative game.  It has tension, luck, skill and teamwork all wrapped up in a game that also has beautiful artwork and packaging.  Very easy to teach to non-gamer folks, yet still entertaining enough to be enjoyable for gamers too.  It also plays in less than a half hour, so you can easily play multiple times or use it as a bridge in between other games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[COLOR=#FF0000][b]+[/b][/COLOR] There is a lot of excitement that goes around in this game. Constantly worrying about what tiles are going to be flooded or removed can make every card draw intense. Hoping that the next treasure card isn't a "water rising" card, or that the next flood isn't the fool's landing tile keeps people on the edge of their seat.

[COLOR=#FF0000][b]+[/b][/COLOR] The theme does shine a bit in this game. Because tiles are constantly flooding, even right after they're drained, it feels like Atlantis sinking in the ocean. Having to have a helicopter card to escape from Fool's Landing is also pretty cool.

[COLOR=#FF0000][b]+[/b][/COLOR] The different characters are pretty cool, and call for a decent amount of special interaction.

[COLOR=#FF0000][b]+[/b][/COLOR] The game scales pretty well, I played it with 2 and with 4 and enjoyed it both times. The downtime isn't bad at all, as you're constantly watching other people's turns to see what could be done to help you or the team.

[COLOR=#FF0000][b]-[/b][/COLOR] Like most co-ops, it can feel a bit like the game throws random events that can't be avoided under any circumstances, but you can avoid these things most of the time through careful planning.

[i] Final thoughts: Pretty good co-op. I'm not usually a huge fan of co-ops, but this one is rather enjoyable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Made by the creator of Pandemic and it shows. If you know how to play the one game, you know how to play the other; they're that similar. Forbidden Island has a more satisfying endgame though.

Forbidden Island is such a simple game, that it is probably too simple for veteran adult gamers. Feels like a kid's game. Not sure if it is possible to lose if everyone is working together. Very easy to explain to new players.

My recommendation is give a copy to your kids or sibling's kids and never turn down a request to play it.

RATING: 6
It's a pretty good value for the price.  On the plus side: The components, art, and overall production value are fantastic. The gameplay is easy to teach and involves some strategy and tactics.  Works well with all player counts, even solo. You can snag it brand new for under 20 bucks, and the box is small enough to slide easily into your collection.

Unfortunately, there's just not enough here.  The strategy is too simple, and satisfying decisions are rare.  Much of the outcome is dictated by which cards come out and the initial layout of the board. There can be some tension when you're having a rough game, but I've still not lost it in 5 plays.  Just feels like it gets played out fast, and isn't even THAT fun the first time through.

Perhaps still worth keeping around as a gateway cooperative game.

RATING: 6.5
I played this after Pandemic, so that is probably why my rating of this game is below a 7.

Forbidden Island has amazing components and it feels cool to play, but it just feels flat when you just got done playing Pandemic.

Don't get me wrong.  I'll play this game.  I'll play it whenever someone is like: 'What's that tin there?' and I'll get all giddy about it.

6.5 isn't a rating for a bad game.  It's a rating for a game I don't actively push for my group to play, but I'll play it and have a smile on the entire time.

Have a light group of boardgamers or want to show those clue and monopoly/vanilla board gamers what there is beyond the Target/Walmart shelves?  Then show them this.  It's super cheap [cheaper than monopoly!] and plays in a fraction of the time and offers an adventure feel for all your friends and family.

RATING: 8
The ideal cooperative game for the whole family.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Streamlining Pandemic and choosing a less dire topic for family play leads to Forbidden Island - a collaborative game with open information (i.e. a multiplayer solitaire) where players have got to rescue four treasures in an island before in sinks in the ocean.

The plot is realised using very few elements - a bar for the water level, tiles for the island, the same amount of cards to make it sink and a few more cards to gather the treasures and provide some help (especially to flee from the island). The different combinations of tiles and setups (some of the island starts already drowned) give the game more staying power, and the different levels of play can keep it thrilling every time.

This is where Forbidden Island's main strength shows: with such a clean cut and such a friendly topic, at the end of every round when a half of the island is under water you can cut the air with a knife - accomplishing the task on time isn't easy, especially with four players, since all the cards are spread around and there must be more exchanges to gather the treasures.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[b]Forbidden Island[/b]

[COLOR=#FF0000][i]~The game that started it all!~[/i][/COLOR]

[i]- Great gateway game for families, easy to learn.
- Accessable to younger kids since it's a co-op (I starting playing with my girls when they were 5).
- Beautiful components and great artwork on the tiles.
- The only co-op in our collection (we've gotten rid of Flash Point Fire Rescue, Forbidden Desert, Pandemic, Pandemic Dice, Pandemic Legacy and Robinson Crusoe).

Our first designer board game, this is the game that got my family and I into this hobby. This game helped teach my kids how to cooperate when playing games and not to take gaming too seriously. It also helped my kids to learn to lose gracefully, especially since we all lost![/i]

RATING: 6
I almost purchased Pandemic, and then read about Forbidden Island.  Both feature cooperative play, but the theme and beauty of Forbidden Island won me over.  Although it's inexpensive (another plus!), the quality of this game is unbelievable: thick tiles with gorgeous artwork, matching cards, delightfully detailed treasure figurines, wooden pawns--and it all comes packed in a beautiful tin box!  The rules booklet is clear and concise, and play is straightforward.  It's easy to learn, but requires attentive coordination of effort to win.  The cooperative mode of play makes for a nice change of pace, and it's also very well-suited to solo play.  (3+3) solo plays: 3

RATING: 7.25
Excellent game! Initially when I bought it I read too many reviews of this game and became persuaded or maybe even jaded into thinking that this was just Pandemic. I actually felt like I did not like this game that much upon our initial plays. Well, we gave it a break and played later on when the mood was right and I found I do enjoy this game in its own right. 

This game is rich in theme and enjoyable to play. The components are really outstanding and the artwork is stunning. A great cooperative game of getting the treasures before the island sinks. Sure the mechanics are the same as another game, but that doesn't matter. Good solid mechanics and a fresh new theme completely change a game experience for it's players. 

Also, there is a wonderful set of Arts Cow cards that really make this game even more fun to play. The set includes many new roles, new tile layouts and a traitor variant.

RATING: 8

As the dunes rise, you always have the feeling you COULD dig if you needed to, but with the island, once a portion is sunk, it's gone.  So, yeah, some people will say if you have Desert, you don't need Island -- I think there's room for both.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This has been well received by family and gamers alike as a co-operative venture, where you get to jointly overcome the game rather than compete against each other. And there's no accidental about it - you *have* to co-operate to win by sharing and consolidating the treasure cards you pick up into one person's hand. Turns are generally straightforward - you're moving around (each tile is an action) to get next to a flooded (flipped) tile and undo the flood (because if it floods again, you'll lose that tile) or you're moving to someone else's spot and giving them a card. Once someone gets 4 of a kind, they trade it in on the right tile for 1 of the 4 treasures. Once you have all 4 treasures, everyone get to the home tile and play a helicopter card to win. So the game is all moving, flipping, sharing. It's easy enough for smart 7 year olds to pick up, and good for family, although it can be hard for kids to kick the competitive habit and truly understand that it really doesn't matter who saves the treasure without the need to get sulky. A good result is dependent on your ability to not have to spend actions moving, instead saving them for card sharing and flipping / saving tiles. It’s especially so at the harder levels. And this will depend on how the treasure cards come out (you want each player to receive just 1 type rather than each type being split amongst everyone) and whether the flood tiles are close to you or further away. The more you play, the more you realise your result is a function of this card distribution. The available actions are limited. The interesting and challenging choices that those used to the dynamism and broad possibilities of Pandemic may expect are not there, so it certainly doesn't replace it on the shelves. But it can be fun if everyone plays in good spirit. It creates some tension along the way and offers a nice sense of satisfaction when you succeed. It has its niche, and it racked up 10 plays in a matter of days so I’m starting this as an 8, but I could see it dropping to a 7 over time as we continue to do all the right things and become slightly disillusioned with the luck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
see forbidden desert

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.2
One of the first games in my collection and for that alone there will always be a place in my heart for it. I used to adore the tin and laughed at the haters, but as my collection grows I find myself turning against tins more and more every day.

A fan game if you don't take it seriously.

To me it is basically a one player game that is boring to play alone. If you prefer it is an exciting puzzle for a group of people to solve together, but the "players" thing is a joke. You could play it alone, you could play it with ten of your friends. 

Other than that enjoyable, light, very easy to get into for ANYBODY, but should be used as an exciting filler. No chance inviting friends in order to play Forbidden Island. 

I feel that this is a great game to play with kids. The mechanics is almost exlusively kids oriented in my opinion. (That's my main problem with pandemic, it has kids mechanics but it tries to be an adult game). 

The most irritating feature of this line of leacock games is that the game doesn't end only when the island sinks (or when the whole world is hopelessly infected) it can also end when you draw a predetermined number of Waters Rise cards (or when the players deck ends for Pandemic). In my opinion this is a preposterous, cheap and extremely unthematic trick that makes me mad every time I think about it. I mean how can the water rise at a level of drowning everyone, while at the same time there are parts of the island that are perfectly dry. 

The next worse thing about the game (also present in pandemic) is that no one (except for the person guiding other players) has the feeling that actually plays his character and that his actions matter. In forbiden island I can see an adult peacfuly guiding children and letting them have fun. But I can't help from laughing when I see experienced pandemic players trying to be polite while patronizing other adults and trying to hide their pain when an obviously bad move is proposed. 

- "We could do that, OR MAYBE it would be better to do this and this and this and then Mary will do this and this and the other and then it's my turn again"
- "OK, let's do it that way, and then we can play a game that I can be a part of."

It remind's me when a friend of ours told us that we can have a shooting contest with his Dad's hunting rifle, but because it will be dangerous he would take our shots too. And then he started shooting going like this: "Now I am shooting for me, now I am shooting for Nick, now I am shooting for Paul (and so on)"

That is why I can see this game only in a non serious-kids context.

Great artwork and great quality of the island tiles (although cheap treasures)

(Wife's Point of View: She finds it completely boring)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Forbidden Island really does seem like Pandemic for people who can't handle Pandemic (whether that be kids or non-gamers).  Here, you're trying to collect four artifacts by amassing four cards of the same color in your hand, with the usual Pandemic rules about drawing and trading cards.  The tiles that make up the game board can become flooded and then removed from the game, when the "water rises" cards, which work just like epidemic cards in Pandemic, come up.  Like in Pandemic, the key mechanism is that the cards get stacked back on top of the deck and are likely to be drawn again.  However, in this game certain locations are more important than others (particularly Fools Landing), and if their associated cards come out early, the game will be much harder.  Furthermore, I found that there was generally less to do on your turn.  I'm not a big fan of Pandemic to begin with, and this game is definitely inferior.

(1 play)

RATING: 10
Simple rules, fast-paced play, and beautiful artwork on the  "board" combine to make this a favorite of ours. Given how simple it is, there's a lot variation from one game to the next due to the different initial set-up of the island and the different player roles. We've found that it gets distinctly harder with fewer players, as the limited number of treasure cards you can hold in only two hands means you  frequently have to cycle through the deck repeatedly to get matching sets of four.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game has been great with young children, who really take to the idea of playing a game where everyone wins or loses together. The kids really get into the theme of escaping a sinking island. The components are fantastic. 

The first of two possible faults would be that the game can be susceptible to one player taking charge. This might be fixed by a "no bullhorn" policy where players whose pawns are isolated by two squares cannot communicate with other players. The other complaint might be that the game is too easy to beat, but that's easily fixed by the fan-made variant island shapes.

RATING: 6
Forbidden Island will stay in my collection, and gets a lot of plays, because it's a fantastic way to introduce new players to cooperative games.  There are far better games employing the same general mechanics, but they are too heavy for kids and nongamers, and they are discouraging.  Forbidden Island is light and, at normal difficulty, quite beatable, so it'll be my go-to "gateway game" for co-ops.

RATING: 8
At client site (3 copies) used for training on team dynamics now...

I gave this to my son for his 9th birthday; this is incredibly good.  We (just the two of us) played Novice and won, but half the island was gone, so not sure I'd call it an easy victory.  It actually is well balanced, in understanding the game play, you will get the water rise cards more often with more players and have more coordination to pass cards to the right players needing them as you add more players.  Captures the feel of Pandemic in a more kid-friendly format.

RATING: 7
A lot of my friends like this more than I do... And I like it. RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is definitely "Pandemic Light" but that's not a bad thing. I'd often rather play this than its bigger brother. It's a simpler, lighter, and faster game. It replaces the familiar virus outbreaks in Pandemic with an island which dynamically sinks, one segment at a time. It's usually nicely timed such that the team is beating a hasty retreat to the helocopter just as things are falling apart all around them. It's easier to win, though to my mind that makes it less frustrating, and the shorter investment means it's less annoying when you lose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My family enjoys it.  I think I like it more than they do.  Fun design.  Characters remind me of Pandemic.  The game may be worst encourager of alpha player dominance.  I even have to monitor myself.  Stress is real as game goes on.  I swear my feet start to feel wet.  Fairly quick fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
There is a tremendous amount of unavoidable randomness. I prefer games to end with the feeling, "I wish I had done this differently," but every game of Forbidden Island merely ends with, "I wish this had happened differently," typically related to the random drawing of Water Rises cards. Having played two games last night, the first game literally lasted three turns, when we drew back-to-back Waters Rises cards causing Fool's Landing to become submerged. We won our second game but there was no sense of accomplishment, just "Oh, we didn't get randomly screwed this time."

Besides that, the amount of agency each player has on the game is practically zero. You can go for a 15 minute smoke break and come back and see what players have decided for you to do on your turn. Perhaps in this way it's a "true cooperative" game, in the same way Solitaire could be a true cooperative game. But I strongly prefer cooperative games like Hanabi where players are forced to make their own decisions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A little less complex than its big brother "Forbidden Desert" We picked this one up on vacation at a tiny little FLGS on an island. Haha, but true. 

It plays well. I think it would work better with younger children than Forbidden Desert because it's not quite as brutal. As you sink areas of the island, their cards cease to have an impact. The longer the game goes on, the more of the island sinks and the greater the number of "reprieves" you get from random chance. So While Forbidden Dessert tends to accelerate and bear down on you as the game goes on, Forbidden Island tends to attenuate and almost help you get across the finish line. Although life is not like this, it's probably not a bad thing for playing with kids who might not understand the fun in having a game pummel you into the ground ;-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Pandemic's little brother. But a little brother stepping out of the shadows. I love the Pandemic style of game, a mixture of set collection while sticking your finger into the dike. Forbidden Island can be more appealing than Pandemic in a number of ways.

1. Less set up time.
2. Simpler (Lily is able to play it and understand what she is doing and why she needs to do it).
3. A bit less stressful. My God, Pandemic can get your heart racing to unhealthy levels.

Pandemic-lite is a bit unfair, but it's the best way to describe and to also explain why we like it so much.

RATING: 7.5
I really enjoy the changing map. It adds an excellent variety to a game that might otherwise have a memorisable solution. The changing roles also add a nice dimension of variety to the game (though some of them are next to useless - I'm looking at you, explorer). My main criticism would be that a lot of the game is decided once the roles are dealt out. A game with the diver and explorer, for instance, is a lot worse off than one with a pilot and messenger. I do have fun, though, and it can get exciting once everything starts going wrong.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I played Pandemic early on in getting into the hobby, and was really impressed by the mechanics. But I soon decided I'm not a big fan of co-ops, especially after a painful game (my first win!) where we were bossed around by an experienced player. My mother-in-law picked up Forbidden Island for me in the Borders liquidation sale, so I gave it a go, and it really does merit the description of "Pandemic Lite". The mechanics are still clever (though not as clever as Pandemic), it's faster and it should work better for non-gamers. I don't like the theme nearly as much though, and this has left the collection now.

RATING: 7.5
7.5 - I played this and the other 2 Matt Leacock co-op games, Forbidden Desert and Pandemic, and found this one to be the least stressful and most manageable game of the three.  There is lots of time if you are careful and work together unlike pandemic where if you don't keep a close watch on the player deck you'll run out of moves.  The board is less chaotic than forbidden desert with it's constantly shifting tornado.  I find this game very enjoyable and the randomized layout makes the difficulty vary from game to game and it has many of the same elements that the other two games have.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My favourite first-level gateway game that is a much lighter version of its famous cousin, Pandemic. 

Forbidden Island serves as a good introduction to the cooperative games genre and the easy to understand rules, interesting theme (treasure hunters who have to steal 4 priceless artifacts from an ancient, mysterious island before it sinks), and never a dull moment during play make this a lovely game. 

Some people say it lacks replayability, but I disagree. One just has to find (or devise) variant tile layouts (which represent the Island's shape) and each game is new with a different set of challenges.

RATING: 7
This is a cooperative game that keeps things concise. Its art is awesome and the rule are easy to understand, and it 's on the short side. Everyone I know has had this experience: the first few times, they absolutely love it. Then, after a couple of plays, they figure out a few key tactical principles and the strategy evaporates, as each turn's best play becomes easy to identify and the game becomes dull. I have hope that some of the fan expansions on BGG will revitalize this one, just be aware of the possibility that this game will burn bright and then flame out.

RATING: 6.9
This was one of the first games I was eager to get because of how impressive it looked in a tin. Not only that but how diverse the idea of a sinking island and you had to save the jewels and artifacts. Indiana Jones at its finest. It's a simple game with a few decks of cards. One determines the tiles which sink.Another determines which artefacts are going to be rescued first. And lastly there are the cards which determine when the island sinks. Very similar in mechanism to pandemics Epidemic cards. These happen to be called Waters rise. It's a very tense game from start to finish and thoroughly enjoyable too. The pawns could have been nicer. But that's just picking. Worth playing.

RATING: 7

That being said, while I don't think this game is up to the complexity of other Co-ops; for me I actually enjoy this game as much as those because it plays really fast. This game plays in thirty minutes and I can play it with my kids. Solid game; nothing to write home about, but does hit the table and gets the blood pumping as the island starts sinking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
Fun cooperative game.  The rules are very simple and the game doesn't take long to teach.  My 9 and 7 year old sons can play and offer decent strategic input.  Despite the simple rules, the game can be quite challenging, and it allows you to vary the difficulty to your liking.  There's a decent balance of luck and strategy involved in this game.  And there's a decent amount of replayability here, since the island and the role cards will generally be configured differently each time you play.

Forbidden Island has a feeling very similar to Pandemic, if you have ever played that game.  Several of the mechanics are very similar.  But Forbidden Island is a nice alternative because it plays faster, and I think the rules are a lot easier for children to comprehend.  This is a game I definitely don't regret purchasing, especially considering its reasonable price.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Considering what you pay for this game, it's very easy to recommend to most anyone. Of the games I've played, we've won about 50% of the time and the wins always come down to the wire. It's a great first-game-of-the-night to get everyone in the mood for heavier affairs later on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Forbidden Island is a slightly more simplistic version of Pandemic (a big favorite of mine).  In this case, adventurers are attempting to obtain 4 treasures scattered about an island that is slowly sinking beneath the waves and escape from the island.  Anyone who has played Pandemic will be familiar with the mechanisms at work here, so if you enjoy Pandemic you'll like Forbidden Island.

Things I like :
-In general, nice components.  There are 4 cool "treasure" pieces that kids (and adults) will enjoy.  Tiles are solid as well, and the whole game comes in a nice tin.  Cards aren't quite as durable as I would like them.
-The basic mechanism of the game.  I enjoyed it in Pandemic as well.
-Quick play time.  Plays a bit faster than Pandemic, which is nice if you have someone with a short attention span for games.  Could also use it to teach Pandemic.
-It is a low cost game.

Things I don't like :
-it is, pretty much, the same game as Pandemic except simpler.  If I am in the mood for this type of game, I will likely just play Pandemic instead.
-As I mentioned before, I wish the cards were more durable.

Bottom line, I think Forbidden Island is a good game, but there isn't much there for someone who already owns Pandemic.  I think it is a nice game to play with children or adults who aren't into longer games (or maybe find the disease theme too depressing).

RATING: 7.1

I started playing with my 4 and 5 year old (who are now 5 and 6) and they were able to pick up a good portion of the key strategy. There are several roles (diver in particular) that add more depth to the strategy.

Not something I'm ever looking to pull out unless I want to teach someone co-op games or get kids interested, but it's great for both of those situations.

RATING: 7.5
[b]26 plays in:[/b]
25 of my plays have been solo. I was certainly a bit addicted to this game for a few weeks. Even worked up a half-baked variant I named Forbidden Archipelago! I cooled a bit, but recently played a few games and still had a fun time. Enjoyable game, plays quickly, easy to grasp the rules, lots of variant possibility both with the rules from the box and via fan ideas.

I've enjoyed my solo plays. The variant island layouts and multiple starting difficulties add a lot of replay. I'm hoping to play through (and achieve victory on) at least the 10 official variants and then possibly moving on to some of the various fan created (or maybe make up some of my own) islands. I think I've played 6 of the official islands so far.

Elite is probably my favorite starting level. You get two full runs through the Treasure Deck before the possibility of flooding out which gives you a reasonable shot at victory. Legendary is also fun, but there is a much greater chance of an average to poor luck shuffle dooming you no matter what you do.

The one play with others was at my FLGS with three other experienced gamers. Surprisingly I didn't like it as much as I have solo. I think it's because I was playing new games that day and having a lot of fun doing that. With a different group (family or more casual) I expect this will truly shine.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.9
If you played Pandemic and didn't like it don't bother with this. If you played Pandemic and liked it (and why wouldn't you, its excellent) then don't bother with this.

Players search a sinking Island for a four hidden treasures while it sinks around them. Treasures are claimed by forming sets of four cards of the same type. Each turn players move, claim cards, and a bit more of the island sinks. Critically all the players work as a team, this is like Pandemic a true co-op. However, where Pandemic is very carefully balanced all the little nuances are broken away here, so the game is massively dependent on luck, there is little relationship between the board and hand, with players really just waiting around to see if they draw the right cards.

If Pandemic didn't exist this might make a light fun game, but given that Pandemic does this isn't worth playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Forbidden Island is a great game for younger audiences, or people you're trying to get into more complex co-operative games. The game is fun, easy to play, has surprisingly beautiful artwork (and box!) and doesn't eat up a lot of your time for game night.

The easiest way to describe the game is by calling it 'Pandemic lite'. Players take turns moving around a sinking island, trying to keep it afloat through various actions. At the end of each round, the player draws 2 treasure cards which could be one of 4 treasures, a few actions, or a 'waters rise' card. Next the player draws flood cards equal to the current water level, flipping over the island tiles that become flooded, or removing already flooded tiles from the game. Players win when they turn in 4 matching treasure cards to collect each of the game's 4 treasures and escape the island, and lose if the locations to claim treasures or their evac point ever sink.

Overall, Forbidden Island might have a hard time holding the attention of gamers used to more complex titles like Arkham Horror or Pandemic, but is a great game for slow nights, kids, and friends who are just getting into cooperative gaming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2010-10 B & N

With the different tile layouts it keeps it from getting samey. It got played a lot when we first got it, not sure how much more it'll get played, maybe as the boy gets older.

RATING: 10
What can I say about this game that is bad? Almost nothing.

Highest quality pieces and tiles and cards of any game I have ever touched. 100% best quality pieces. Even comes in a nice TIN!!

Cheap too, oddly enough. 

Our first co-op game. Still love it. I have no complaints. Once you learn the rules and mechanics, there is nothing complicated. Good for many players or just 2. 

Seriously, the only thing to say bad is that the game could have had more variants and a boggier board, I guess. Also, after like 20 games, I don't feel like playing it much anymore. That is common, and will probably change though.

Some of the grooviness of this game though is how compact it is while delivering a full size game experience. I love showing this game to others. It is a permanent part of our collection. One of the best games ever made IMHO.

Recently I played Pandemic. If you like Forbidden Island, you will probably like Pandemic. Forbidden Island is quaint and smallish and beautiful. Pandemic is more like risk mixed with Forbidden Island. Both fun co-op games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
If you know Pandemic, you can see the genesis of this game in that one.  If you don't, here is the cooperative race against disaster but in a much more family (and kid) friendly format.  Instead of diseases and outbreaks, the island is getting flooded and perhaps disappearing.  Players/Explorers race to collect 4 treasures and fly away.  Things that make it simpler - fewer ways to lose and those that are there are easier to track.  (No outbreak upon outbreak sucking up the cubes, no outbreak death count) and the treasure deck is reshuffled, so bypassed cards can be gone after later in the game.  A fixed number of disaster (Waters Rise) cards, so can play safer if all are gone from the deck (prior to reshuffle).  And once a treasure is achieved - those island tiles can be sacrificed as necessary.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fun game that's light on strategy; my only complaint is that it's rarely difficult to win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The very cool thing about this game is that it's cooperative - that is, you're not playing against each other, but together against the game itself. In this case, everyone is trying to unearth all the treasures and leave the island before it sinks into the ocean. I'm not against competition, but I think there's a real need for this kind of cooperative-style, non-competitive board game. That said, my one complaint is this (and it's probably unavoidable with any cooperative game): it's very easy for one person - usually me, if I'm just playing with the kids - to "hijack" the game and dictate what the team strategy should be. But we all love to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Fairly simple cooperative game in the same vane as Pandemic.  You are  a group of explorers trying to gather artifacts and escape the island before the island sinks into the water. Each turn more and more parts of the island start sinking getting more difficult as the game goes on. Players have to work together to make the best moves possible with each players individual abilities. 

Pros: Easy Gameplay. Interaction with other players a necessity. Quick Gameplay time. Fast set up

Cons: simplistic gameplay does not offer a lot of different options. Difficult to play with players who take over decisions for the group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Corlyn Downloads 8/20/2013
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Theme?  Ancient treasures, foolhardy adventurers, a cursed island rapidly sinking into the ocean depths...check!  

Production?  The components are astounding, and demonstrate Gamewright's strength as a publisher.  The tiles and cards are of good stock and gorgeously illustrated with colorful, diverse, evocative landscapes, giving each tile its own flavor and identity.  Finally, the treasures themselves are nice, chunky plastic and look amazing!  You will actually want to succeed in the game so as to acquire them....check!  

Gameplay?  Though it might be too simple for some, Forbidden Island is a fast, fun, exhilarating cooperative adventure that stresses group hand management and proper planning.  It is prone to the Alpha Gamer problem, but that's dependent on group dynamics.  The flooding mechanism is rather clever, and brings genuine suspense to the experience. The race against the clock is exciting, as you try to gather all the treasures, get to Fool's Landing, and get off the island before you sink with it!  It just makes you want to succeed as a team!....check!  

This is one of my favorite games, and it coasts pretty heavily on its awesome theme.  Aside from being insanely affordable ($15 or less), this is a perfect introductory co-op, simple, quick to play, and a great time for all involved.  Works very well with kids.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good starter co-op game, easy to learn, good enough for family game night.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Kids really liked this game, having to choose priorities to save certain parts of the island, which cards to keep, which cards to use in the appropriate moment. Then as the island is almost completely sunk towards the end of the game, the tension of actually making it off the island, is the next 2 cards drawn going to contain the helicopter or waters rise? 

Adults will likely find that decisions are fairly obvious, so may want to progress to Pandemic which offers more options. This makes Forbidden Island very much a family game for younger kids.

Artwork on tiles and cards are just awesome, the treasure pieces are cool to look at with a lot of detail, I wish all games were produced at this level. To add the icing on the cake, its not that expensive to purchase... Wow, a good game with nice graphics, nice game bits, nice game play, and kids enjoy.... what's not to like?

RATING: 5
Pandemic stripped to its bare bones. A lot easier to explain and quicker to "get it", and much easier setup, but less depth and immersion (since most of the time, it's just, on your turn, unflipping tiles that were just flipped). The modular board and flip/unflip are cool, especially the latter, which looks more dramatic when compared to Pandemic's 1-3 cube threshold. But the great loss to me is Pandemic's accessible and gripping theme.

3+2

RATING: 8

You know what I mean. The best part about this game is the challenge. This game is so well constructed!! The challenge and reward of surviving the Forbidden Island is way too much fun. To this day, it's one of my favorite games and very sentimental. The perfect game to start your tabletop spree. The theme, challenge, co-op feel, and addiction make this a GREAT game.

RATING: 8
Forbidden Island -- 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Pandemic lite. 

the good: 
- It retains the main AI mechanic of Pandemic which put both the parent and the child quite ahead of competition. This AI makes planning possible as player are not just reacting against the game. 
- art is nice and makes the game more approachable for target audience (teens, families)
- time frame being shorter also makes the game far better for the mentioned audience.  
- with 6 roles in the base game and island being modular, there's quite a lot of replayability. 
- AI deck getting thinner as the game goes on is clever and makes the game tenser and tenser. 

the bad:
- well it's harder to keep track of which areas are more likely to be targeted than others as there's only 2 states of an area (normal, flooded) before it's drowned  as opposed to 4 states in Pandemic. FI is therefore not as strategic as Pandemic. But has it's own challenges. 

the ugly
- Playing Schmidt version. The card stock far too thin. Yes the game is cheap to buy, but I'd prefer they left out the 4 statues (that do nothing) for a better card stock. Unlike Pandemic these cards need to get sleeved.

- Slovene translation is one of the lamest jobs I've seen. Here's what they've done: they used normal colour laser printer (probably in their office) and printed card translations on normal laser printer stickers. The quality is not bad, it's terrible. I'm not sure there's a worse paper available, so colours bleed and it's hard to read the text (which is even smaller than original). Even worse, the person who did the graphic part of this translation was either grossly underpaid or amateur (or both) as they didn't even bother to find the font which has Slovene special letters included. 
And there's also a rulebook which is: scanned original, white lines put over the original text and new text on top (same printer, same quality). And the translations are in some places so literal from German it makes no sense ("prostor neuspeha"??? - gre za helikoptersko pristajališče/ploščad).
 [I'm ignoring Slevene butchered version in the ratings. The rating is for what the publisher put out]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pandemic-lite. In a good way.

Great gateway game for kids. It's a co-op style game where players have three actions to move their characters (each with individual skills) around a board (comprising tiles). Objective is to gather four-of-a-kind cards to claim four treasures before getting off 'Forbidden Island'.

Some of the tension is lost because cards get recycled (unlike Pandemic) and it becomes an exercise in waiting for the right cards to turn up while stemming the flooding of the islands.

Great for kids but trades the tension of Pandemic for a lighter, easier system.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love this game. It's a fast, fun, friendly, and easy co-op that's small, portable, and fast to set up. The only downfall of forbidden island is that it's pretty dependent on the amount of players; i.e. you're pretty much guaranteed to win with 4 players, but with 2 on a high level it's impossible and entirely dependent on the cards drawn. This game would also be really good for an entry-level gamer and is very teachable. Considering how cheap Forbidden Island is, the quality of the components is really good. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bit too simple to make me choose it, similar game play to Pandemic, but lacks the complexities and excitement. Good to get kids playing though, my 4 year old loves it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A fun, light cooperative game. It was one of the first games we owned and was a great gateway into the hobby. It is a little too simple now, but the set collection and trading of cards does add a nice level of stress to each game, and all games do seem to come down to the very end before getting off the island. I would happily play this game with some new gamers or with some kids, as it is very easy to understand the rules. The main issue is that there are just a lot of other games out there that take 30ish minutes that are a lot more fun that Forbidden Island.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is definitely a unique game for its purely cooperative element.  With up to 6 players all working together to achieve the game's goal of gathering for ancient artifacts before the island sinks provides an atmosphere during play that is much more naturally than any traditional game of forced competitive interactions.

The downside (or maybe the upside for some) is that FI is exceedingly simple... almost simplistic. But it's entertaining in a light way for about 30-45 minutes.  Well worth it as an intermission game in your regular regime of more strategic entertainment and quickly learn-able by almost all ages. Take a break from bashing at each other on Forbidden Island.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Initially I thought this was a great game, however, I think a lot less of it right now. The general structure of gameplay, a). do several actions, b). draw 2 cards, c). make the world a worse place, is borrowed from Pandemic. This wouldn't be so bad if the game didn't feel so similar on the basic level. Even though you're not curing diseases but shoring up tiles, both games start to blur until at some point you're just saving yourself from losing, however it's called. 

The people that I could recommend this game to are parents of young children or people who want to introduce their friends to board gaming. This is simple enough to be easily explained to pretty much anyone. On the other hand, it lacks the crunch offered by Pandemic and after a few games, you'll yearn for something more complex.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
pleasantly sized co-operative modular board tile based adventure game. "pandemic lite" I like it better than pandemic...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[2012-08-25]
Ghost Stories és Pandemic közös gyermeke szinte szó szerint. Mindent a szüleitől örökölt és lett egy kis fiúcska, ami annyit tesz, hogy igazi kis egyszerű családi kooperatív játék született. A GS-hez hasonlóan különböző szerepű karaktereink vannak, akik a GS-hez hasonlóan mozognak az egyes térképlapokon csak átlósan nem. A célunk egy sziget 4 kincsének megszerezése annak elsüllyedése előtt. Itt jön képbe a másik szülő, minden játékos kőre végén adott mennyiségű áradás lapot húzunk, amivel helyzetünk lesz egyre nehezebb. Mindegyik karakternek van valamilyen speciális tulajdonsága, talán ebben a játékban kevésbé éreztem, hogy nagy különbségek lennének köztük, mint esetleg a Pandemicben. Nagyon egyszerű, talán az eddigi legegyszerűbb koop játék, amivel találkoztam, így családdal is bátran játszható, sőt főként velük, mert nem igazán megterhelő egy-egy köre a társasozónak. Nagyon gyorsan lemegy egy parti, mi kell még? Semmi új ötlet, de kellemes darab.

RATING: 8
Forbidden Island is by now a classic cooperative game that was one of my early introductions into hobby board gaming. It borrows a lot from one of Matt Leacock's other coops, Pandemic, but is lighter in theme and price. If you're trying to bring in new player to hobby board gaming, this is an excellent starting point. The production is excellent, despite the annoying tin, and even though this game has been lost underneath a glut of newer coops, it's still one of the best and one of my favorites. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I prefer to play competitively and I want to win against another player, but this game removes the player vs player aspect and replaces it with cooperation. I generally hate cooperation games but I played this game with a 6 year old and an 11 year old and they absolutely loved it. Instead of getting crushed by an adult (remember, I play competitively - and I make no exceptions!), we all got to work together, planning our next move and we won. I would have tossed the game otherwise, but since kids were so happy, I decided to try the game again with my girlfriend. Same result - I was lukewarm, but she was delighted that instead of getting killed in another game, we won together! Like it or not, this one's a keeper, if only to keep the kids and the girlfriends happy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
We LOVE co-op games. My husband and I are highly competitive so it is nice to feel like we don't have to "fight" other players and have our ideal win scenarios "foiled". 

The drop-in, drop-out groups we play with tend to be somewhere in the middle between casual and hardcore. Capable of appreciating and understanding rules more complex than Milton Bradley games yet don't have the time to play games like Eclipse and Twilight Imperium 3. This game hits the table a bit because of this reason alone.

While not as good persay as Pandemic, it has a few enjoyable difficulty twists. Once we even lost the game before it started because, well, the waters rose.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
1 play, solo (just about the only way I play co-ops), elite difficulty, 2 roles (Navigator, Engineer)

Nice simplification of the Pandemic system: easier setup for both the board (random configuration of tiles) and decks (just shuffle and you're ready to go!). Rules are also easier to manage during the game: 3 actions (move/shore up/give card/turn in a set of 4). And production is great, with a nice tin and cool little treasure minis. Unfortunately, that the completely random draw deck, where Flood Rise cards can now clump up and appear in rapid succession right from the start, makes success even more dependent on luck of the shuffle. The inability to take cards limits you as well, such that sometimes there's just no good option for an action.

I can see that this might be quite good as a family game or as an introduction to co-ops. But it's just not for me (keeping in mind that I don't like co-ops anyway, this is as a rating for the solo game).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

RATING: 8

So as a family game, I would rate this a 10 and as a game to be played with fellow gamer, this would be a 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating this is one of my more interesting dilemmas.  Normally I have no problems with rating games designed for adults and rating games designed for kids, and each catagory I rate with entirely separate criteria.  If a kids game is brilliant, I'll give it a 9-10 even if it would be a 2 with adults--if my daughter's play with our family and her friends warrents a high score it will get a high score--after all, no adult should be fooled into unsuspectingly playing a kids' game.  It's unfair to rank a kids game by adult standards, and BGG is sickenly rife with just such problem scores.  

But herein lies my problem for here is a game which is primarily for 'adults' with its ages 10 and up rating, and yet as a game for adults I'd be hard-pressed to ever want to play again, and the rating should hover around 4 to 5.  

It's (barely) tolerable, but really, there are hundreds of games in my collection which I would bring out to play on game night before this one.

Yet, at the same time, played with my daughter, fully 3 years under the recommended age, it's not only tolerable, but fun.  She brings a visceral excitement to the game which, for me, is utterly lacking intrinsically in the play.  With her in the game it easily ranks a 9 or even a 10...I would not turn down a game with her, nor even try and steer her to a different selection.

So the upshot is, if unlike me, you actually enjoy playing against a random system and not against other thinking players, if you covet that time with you and your friends against the designer's spreadsheet, well you'll possibly like this...although fair warning it is very simplistic if you compare the 'system' against something like Battlestar Galactica or Arkham Horror.  

And right there lies its gift to young kids, because it is very much like those games, only simplified to a state that they can make solid, informed decisions, and contribute greatly to the game themselves without being led by their elders.  And yet it doesn't play like typical kids-game fare...caught up in the children's excitement, you don't notice how pointless and boring it might be if the next card sinks your only chance at the wind-statue, even though your play may have been perfect, because well, the luck of the draw entirely determined it and there's nothing you can do about it.  No, instead you find yourself caught up in their tension to see what the next card will bring, in the edge-of-their-seat excitement to see whether they shored-up the right card on their turn.

This game is a 9.5 if played with young kids
This game is a 4+ if played with gaming adults
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is the first co-op game I played. The rules and playing steps seem too complex at first but that is not a problem to have the excitement from this game. I like that the cooperative spirit and management skills of players are important factors in order to win the game (to get four treasures out of the island before it sinks), unlike other games that players almost kill each other before game ends. Also, game varieties are multiple according to the difficulty level you set before game starts and different changing roles given to players. The game guarantees high replays and  beautiful graphic illustration that surely attracts young and veteran gamers alike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
:thumbsup: LIKE
+ great production value and price
+ tense gameplay that's easy to teach
+ variable difficulty and setup helps keep the game fresh

:thumbsdown: DISLIKE
- it's a full coop game so alpha gamer and samey game are a problem

:star: VERDICT
I'm not the the biggest full coop game fan, but this one is easily my favorite.  It's less abstract than Pandemic and suffer less from the dictator problem.  The tension really builds up during play. For the price and production quality you can't go wrong; great job Gamewright!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I just think this is a brilliant game for its audience. 

While there's no doubt that it's Pandemic's little brother, the (arguably) more engaging theme and components and the more transparent strategy make it very accessible as a family game.

While the strategic depth is lessened slightly, where it beats its older sibling hands-down for me is in its story arc. At the beginning, you feel like you can keep things under control, but as the island starts to sink, you really feel the tension rise, right up until the point where you lift off in your helicopter (sometimes off of the very last tile remaining in the island!). Whereas Pandemic sometimes ends with players saying, "Oh, we're done?", Forbidden Island has a very satisfying ending.

I love Pandemic, especially with the expansion, but Forbidden Island has earned its own place on my shelves, especially with its small price and short setup and playing times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I just received 'Forbidden Island' as a Christmas gift, and it is my first experience in co-operative board gaming.

After opening the tin, the first thing that stood out was the amazingly detailed pieces, cards and tiles. Fantastic artwork on the tiles set the mystical island location, and the pieces of treasure that are to be collected are handsomely crafted. You definitely want to posses these items!

After admiring the components, it was time to set up and play. I've now played the game with 2, 3 and 4 players, and each game was tense and exciting until the end. The rules are fairly simple and straightforward, and you can be up and ready for adventure in mere minutes. Each player is assigned a different role with special abilities. The "board" is also set up uniquely each time you play, adding to the replay value.

My favorite aspect of the game is that winning is not at all easy. Strategy and cooperation between players is necessary for victory, and even your best-laid plans can be thwarted at the last minute. There is one way to win the game: collect all 4 treasures and escape the island. However, there are 4 different ways to lose, and I've lost games by 3 of those ways. To give you a fighting chance, different difficulty levels can be set to fit your ability.

'Forbidden Island' has really gotten me interested in the world of co-op board gaming. There is a spiritual sequel to this game, called 'Forbidden Desert', which I am very highly considering as a purchase. The designer of both 'Forbidden Island' and 'Forbidden Desert' created the game, 'Pandemic', which is another game that is now on my radar.

A beautifully designed game with high-quality components and near endless replay value and excitement, 'Forbidden Island' is a great addition to anyone's board game collection and a great way to get initiated into the world of co-op board gaming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the great collaborative board games. Playing this inspired me to buy Forbidden Desert, which is also a great game, but very similar game mechanics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[Gamewright 2010 Edition] {Island; co-op, action-point-allowance; optimal 4p} {6: adults, 7.5: kids} Forbidden Island is a thematic fun co-op game for children.  Players work together to find 4 treasures, go back to Fools' Island and fly away with a helicopter.

This game is full of interaction and communication.  And this is fun.  Replayablity is not bad, but not a keeper.  So, it's good to buy it cheap second hand and then sell after plays.

It takes a while to explain the games to children because there are multiple action choices, multiple steps, and to warn them about the urgency of shoring up islands.

Difficulty:
- Novice for children, and then increase difficulty as they like challenges.
- Elite for adults.

The game components are nicely made.  The 4 treasures are toy light.  The game tiles are sturdy.  And the illustration is vivid.  The use of colour is good.  All these made Forbidden Island a good family / children game.

-- 
Compare to Pandemic.  Of course this is more friendly.  And I prefer this as the entry co-op game for children.  For adults, always Pandemic.

More of a kids game really and I believe it'd appeal to children younger than the 10+ age suggested by the publisher.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A Pandemic filler. I liked it - fills a Co-op Filler niche which is rare. Nice art on tiles. No art on roles though. Rules are easy to explain. I explained it in 5 mins. Cards were a bit of a cop out - there were only 6 card types for the Hero deck. I find that better in Pandemic; at least in Pandemic, you had the option of using a cure card to travel. In FI, "cure" or treasure cards are used solely for treasure which means that once someone has discarded 4 treasure cards to obtain the treasure then all cards of that type are now useless. I would have liked it better if the cards had more function.

The treasure tokens are amazing though. Anyway I suppose I'm just nitpicking at it. If Zooloretto came out before Coloretto, I'd be nitpicking Coloretto as too simple. But as it is, I enjoy Coloretto for its simplicity and think that Zoo is slightly overdone.

The kids love playing the 'sinking island' game though :)

UPDATE: The official Variant Island Layouts pushes this up from a 6->6.5

RATING: 7
This is a fun very simple coop game.  I would not recommend this game for experienced players but if you want an introductory coop game which is light and easy to learn, there may not be a better option out there.

The biggest negative here is that once you have won it a few times, the game is not complex enough or adjustable enough to make you want to play it more than a few times.  You eventually feel like you either will win by default or if you lose, it is only because you got exceptionally unlucky, not because you made poor choices.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played this for the first time last night with 3 people. It was great fun. All three of us walked away from the game with the feeling of having just experienced a "Indiana Jones" or "Uncharted" adventure. 

The game is cooperative, the players vs. the sinking island. I like these types of games, they provide a distinctly different experience from your standard competitive board game.

The one concern I have with the game is based solely on its core mechanic. The island is sinking. Quickly. In some difficulty levels, VERY quickly. The sinking is handled by random shuffle of a "flood deck" and then a  number of cards (2-5 depending on where you are in the game) gets turned up. Each card that turns up represents an area that becomes flooded, or sinks completely. This, by itself, is not a problem, but the board layout is completely random as well. Finally, there is 1 board location that has no backup location for its function, and is required to win the game. It is entirely possible for this location to be flooded when the game starts, and then sunk in the first turn. You need a very specific sequence of events and combination of player roles, but for all that I can see it happening.

Overall, I enjoyed the game very much, and it is a nice quick game to play with up to 4 people with. I would't play it with less than 3.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Un Pandemic simplifié. Pas mauvais, pas wow, il a la belle qualité d'être rapide.

RATING: 5
I picked this co-op up mainly because it's by the same designer as Pandemic, which I adore. This is a really great family game and it can be a lot of fun, but given the choice I'd pick Pandemic every time. The games are VERY similar, but there are enough differences to justify having both in your collection. Still, some of those differences make gameplay a little clumsy, and you can easily be stuck in scenarios which are quite tedious (mainly due to the reshuffled deck). I still like Forbidden Island pretty well and will keep it around, especially to introduce younger or new gamers to co-ops, but I probably won't play it very often. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This feels like Pandemic boiled down to its very essence. And while less complex and shorter than Pandemic, Forbidden Island is still a great co-op game, exciting to the end, and a good family game. Played this with my 6 year old once and now he's begging me to play again every day!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Too light for me. However, my wife likes it and suggests playing it now and then. Good gateway coop game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pretty much exactly what I had expected, Forbidden Island is Pandemic lite, with the core mechanics stripped down to ease complexity and a family-friendly theme added. For serious gamers, there's still plenty of tension and room for clever play, but the potential audience for this one now grows to include more casual players. Forbidden Island is quick, easy, has an appealing theme and components and succeeds on just about every level. If this had been released before Pandemic, I'd have said it's ticketed for a Spiel des Jahres nomination, but being so derivative of a title that has won so much acclaim so recently, I'm guessing Forbidden Island will be generally ignored in the awards category. Nevertheless, with a price of less than $15 (and probably less than $12 if you scout around a bit), I think the game will sell well for Gamewright, which may pursuade other mainstream U.S. game companies to take a second look at Euro-style games. In the final analysis, Forbidden Island packs a big punch for a small price, strikes a nice balance between gamers' game and gateway game and is well worth a try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
When I bought it, didn't realize it was a clone of Pandemic, just not quite as much fun.

RATING: 8
Very good coop game, simple but fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's like a relaxed version of pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Short, challenging game that requires strategy and cooperation to win. Some luck and chaos too. Theme is rich. Bits are first class. Very cheap price.

Tons of fun. Playing time is about 30 minutes. For me, it definitely has that "Let's play again!" aspect.

About as complex as Pandemic overall but a little shorter. Besides their different themes, a key difference between FI and Pandemic is the board: will be different each game, and it changes during play so you have to adapt and keep your vital routes open.

Gamers should set the initial Water's Level appropriate to their skill level. The lowest settings are more suitable for play with families and kids.

Solitaire is very do-able. (See my session reports for rules variant ideas.)

Forbidden Island is now on my shortlist of best gateway games. I used to think Pandemic was Matt Leacock's masterpiece. But Forbidden Island tops it. 


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
ESSEN 2011
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As many say, "Pandemic Lite" which has its pros in ease to learn, approachable theme, and game time 30-45 minutes. But the major con is that it overall feels lucky. To make the game harder doesn't mean you have to play better because your choices are fairly limited. The strategy space isn't very deep. Once you have found some strong moves and avoid stupid mistakes, it is just the luck of the cards.
Pandemic isn't so different but has more choices which partly means more strategy and partly masks this luck effect.

RATING: 10

RATING: 7.5
This is Pandemic: Spiel des Jahres-edition. No really, it's a streamlined version of Pandemic. And a lean version of a game that already scales on the very light side of gaming, is a strong contender for the SdJ-award to me. I'd be surprised if this would not be nomineed. High quality components, easy rules, fast gameplay, very family-friendly and beautiful artwork. Plain good quality for your (little) money. Plus there's never been a cooperative game that won Spiel des Jahres. It's about time and this is a really pleasant representative of its genre.

RATING: 7
People calling this Pandemic Lite may be correct insofar as there being slightly fewer complexities in this game, but it is an absolute mis-characterization to say this game is easy. As experienced Pandemic players, we played our first game on the Elite difficulty and lost. Not only does this game have all the challenge of mapping out turns and optimizing actions, it also has an engrossing theme with the island sinking and you desperately trying to keep afloat. This game was surprisingly good and I see myself replaying it many times.

RATING: 6
Culled - First wave; Gifted to Macinda

Why we culled it: Forbidden Island is a solid light co-op game. It sets up quickly, offers a bit of variety, and plays well with a group spanning a wide age range. It is susceptible to the classic "quarterback" issue common among team-based co-ops, and that problem tends to be exaggerated if you're actually playing with an age-diverse group. That said, the game is solid. I had the most fun playing it with my nephews, so when it came time to thin out my collection, it was a no-brainer to send it to them, where I can still play and enjoy on occasion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
+ Great artwork for the various locations and nifty little idols to collect. Very good production values for a $15 game.

+ Relatively interesting puzzle the first couple of times.

- Very limited decision space. There is either something obvious to do or it doesn't really matter what to do.

- Not really a game so much as a puzzle to solve together. There are only a few random elements, which make most decisions mostly calculable.

This game was fun for the first couple of games but there never seemed to be another reason to play it again. I bought Pandemic hoping it would make the game more complex/less calculable and gave this one to my mother to try and get her more interested in designer games. All in all, this is a fair amount of setup to get a game on the level of working a Sudoku together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Maybe I'll get tired of this one, but right now I enjoy solo or with others.  It has never failed to win favor with anybody I have introduced it to.

Do yourself a favor and order the Artscow cards designed by user, Grudunza(sp?).  They are FABULOUS and really add lots of variety to the game.  I am quite surprised that a slew of small expansions have not already been published with these, or similar, ideas.  They are top notch.

Update: Rating has settled down to a solid 8 and will likely stay there. Still a great, short experience for almost anyone. I will always prefer Pandemic, but this is a perfect quick fix.

Another observation is that this game may work even for people who don't like Pandemic. Sometimes all of the chrome in Pandemic detracts from people's experience. It makes it overly fiddly or complicated. 

Others may not enjoy the puzzle of beating the game if it takes 45-60 minutes. But they may enjoy the puzzle in 20-30 minutes.




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 4
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 3
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 4
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 5


Overall - 4

RATING: 7
Check out my video review here: [url]http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_z14dTtGBV8[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fast,  light and fun co-op,  Forbidden Island boasts  some fine components,  a bit of atmosphere and a wide range of accessibility,  all in a well designed package.

There is a fair amount of challenge presented here,  which varies depending on the initial set up and the chosen difficulty level.  I think it plays best as a two player puzzle or solo using that same player count - there is just not enough to do to justify the downtime in multi player mode.

With it's variable tile set up and several difficulty levels,  you would tend to think that the game will feel a bit different in each and every play,  but in actuality,  it doesn't.  Played sparingly,  or with children,  this can be quite an enjoyable experience.

Just realize you are in no danger of drowning in the deep here - this island is surrounded by shallow water.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bought this game because it was cheap, it plays in 30 minutes, and it is a game by Matt Leacock. I'd never even listened the game's name.

After getting home, and reading the rules, I realized I bought a cheaper, faster, simpler Pandemic.

I know this is a simplistic analysis, but it really feels like this. And it is not bad. I love Pandemic, and now I can get a similar feel with another game.

A note: being easier to learn does not make this game easier to win. And unlike Pandemic, here you have the need to hurry since your first turn. There's no time to "have everything under control". You have to get the treasures and leave the island. 

Matt Leacock knows "his shit".

I feel that after a lot of play-throughs it gets a bit stale, as nothing really new ever happens anymore, and as you feel you can see whether you can win or lose early on. But still a very solid game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A good and simple (this is also good sometimes) co-op game. It's basically like Pandemic in the main mechanics - the cards that comeback once a trigger is activated, the collection of cards in order to find a treasure/heal a disease, the roles with very clear functions.

However Forbidden Island has one major advantage: the board is modular, so it changes every game. Even the set-up can change (the one I like the most is the Skull Island).

It is fast enough to be a great filler. For it's price, it is a must have.

My review (in portuguese) is [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/834011/forbidden-island-resenha-em-portugues-review-in]here[/url].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

Race to collect the treasures and make a triumphant escape before you are swallowed into the watery abyss!

-Amazing value

Bad:

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is one gorgeous looking game: It is unbelievable how Gamewright managed to offer linnen-textured cards, plastic miniatures, thick tiles, amazing artwork and a tin box for such a low price. And the atmosphere induced by the well-chosen theme is fantastic. Gameplay-wise the game is pleasant enough, with simple rules, a short playing time and sufficient replayability due to the various difficulty settings and random map. Still, I clearly prefer Matt's original masterpiece Pandemic as it offers more tension and is generally more demanding.
UPDATE: Much better with three instead of two players (Elite level)! Nice tension.
UPDATE: The more I play it, the more I feel that success depends largely on the order in which the cards come up. Despite the theme, Pandemic is definitely the better game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.1

RATING: 6
I feel like once you've figured out the roles, it's very easy to predict quite early on whether you are going to lose. If the wrong tiles come up, there is sometimes nothing you can do about it.

I also dislike that once you know the game, you can either dominate or sit back and watch people self-destruct. Neither is a very fun time.

The components are quite nice, however, and this is good for teaching and for younger players.

RATING: 5
Play was really fun the first time (3 player) and even fun the second time.  By the third play (4 player) it started feeling boring and like the same game.  It's definitely a nice, light gateway game and a fun cooperative.  However, it's also easy for one dominant player to control everyone and tell them what to do.

The special abilities are nice, there is definitely an element of tension with the rising waters, and setup is easy.  We might enjoy it more if we start out with the flood meter on a higher difficulty and purposely choose characters with less useful abilities, but we have too many games we enjoy more to bring this out often.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I'll say up front that my rating is getting boosted by the sheer price to quality ratio.  I still can't believe that I picked this game up on Amazon for a little over 12 bucks.  Really top notch quality, plastic treasures, great feel to the cards, thick tiles, and a tin box.  Crazy.

Gameplay-wise, I'd probably give the game a strong "6".  It's my first collaborative game, thought it would be a good intro to the genre, and it didn't disappoint.  The game is extremely easy to grasp after one read-through the 2 page instructions, takes a few minutes to fill in your teammates, and then you're off.  The people I played with on their first play were already chiming in on strategies a round or so in.

The reason I wouldn't rate this higher is the flip side of that coin, this game is pretty simple.  There isn't much variety from game to game, you get different roles, and the placement of tiles switches up, but each play through feels very familiar.   There are no real curve-balls getting thrown at you, either the luck of the cards work in your favor, or they don't.

Enjoyable little game though, I'm for sure going to keep it around for a fast little filler, or as a gateway game, and I'd be happy to play it here and there.

RATING: 5
Beautiful, but vapid.  There are very few meaningful decisions here, and the game basically dictates whether you're going to win or lose -- your actions have much less impact than whether the right people get the right cards at the right time.  What you have is a complicated version of a mass-market game: there's few decisions, the game is very procedural, but the mechanics are difficult enough that it's not really for the tykes. RATING: 6
PERMANENT PLACE IN COLLECTION AS NON-GAMER GAME

UPDATE: A bit too easy, but good for non-gamers/family groups.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Underrated, this race-the-clock fantasy co-op may be the perfect gateway to cooperative gaming.  Not as mechanically complex as Forbidden Desert (its more challenging younger brother), this theme is more colorful and aesthetically pleasing.  In addition, Island plays more quickly, is easier to teach, and can actually prove more challenging than Pandemic, now a classic co-op intro. 

While Forbidden Desert is a monotone yellow, Forbidden Island is a vibrant, art-filled, fantasy adventure.  Though simpler in game mechanics (and perhaps too simple for experienced co-op'ers), the race to beat sinking islands while hunting treasure proves more exciting than Desert's race to remove sand.  Island, despite its more simple rules, can also prove more challenging than Pandemic, depending on the difficulty level setting; Island also plays more quickly and is easier to teach, making it a potential co-op filler (set-up is quicker than either Desert or Pandemic).  If you can't convince someone to play Eldritch Horror, Dead of Winter or the epic Pandemic Legacy (or want to ease them in...ahem), Forbidden Island is a fast-paced and mechanically simple, yet still strategic and exciting, toe-dip into the waters of co-op gaming.

I recommend this to all co-op gamers, even if only as a lure for their friends and family not yet willing to attempt the more challenging and sizeable co-op adventures currently topping the BGG ranks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Even though it's been called "Pandemic Lite", it can be hard to beat!
