------------------------------
NOTICE : Due to my poor spoken & written English, the rest of my comments will be written in French only but you can read my profile for more informations about the kind of games I prefer and how I rated them.
------------------------------

►ÉDITION : n/d
Éditeur, nb joueurs : 2 à 4 joueurs.
Éditeur, durée : 0h30/partie.
Éditeur, âge : 10 ans et plus.

►PUBLIC(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
☺ Jeu thématique (ex : coop ou semi-coop, améritrash, univers adapté).
☺ Jeu familial (pour jeunes et/ou adultes).
☻ Jeu pour jeunes (je crains que son principal intérêt pour des joueurs adultes soit d’y jouer pour leur faire plaisir). 

►JOUEURS, NOMBRE(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
# Nombres non-déterminés.

►COMMENTAIRE(S) ABRÉGÉ(S):
± THÈME : plutôt plaqué; mais agrémente le jeu.
+ Aide de jeu : 1 par joueur. Bien détaillé.
+ Configurations multiples : disposition modulaire.
+ Expériences multiples : plusieurs niveaux de difficulté.
+ Icônes : sont faciles à comprendre ou à mémoriser.

►REMARQUE(S) PERSONNELLE(S):
® Je crains qu’il retienne peu l’intérêt des joueurs lorsque le stade de la nouveauté sera passé.

1e essai à 4 joueurs. Du même auteur et sorti quelques années après Pandémie, il réutilise la mécanique de son prédécesseur (les cartes "danger" étant recyclées au-dessus de la pioche) mais il est plus accessible et se joue plus rapidement. En cela, il a le mérite d’offrir une bonne initiation aux jeux de type coopératifs et c’est la seule situation pour laquelle je le recommanderais.

►JEU(X) COMPARABLE(S) ESSAYÉ(S):
> « Pandémie » (2008) : coopératif (ou semi-coopératif, traître possible, avec l’extension « Au seuil de la catastrophe »).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pandemic Lite pretty much sums up the game.  The role cards and the actions are so similar to its pappy that the game's differences only come in via the end-game conditions, and the way the bad events are even more random.  I suppose there's a possibility that folks might get it for their kids to play, but Pandemic is pretty kid-friendly in its own right.  I further suppose that this is intended to be the stopgap between the people who would be interested in cooperative games and the more hobby-ish games that fall into that category, but I'm not sure I see why anyone who already likes Pandemic would choose this game over it, save for variety.

-----

1 play: 2 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This feels like a streamlined, stripped-down version of Pandemic to me. Normally, I would think of that as a good thing, as my favorite games tend to be ones with the most straightforward rule sets. However, in this case, I think the result feels more like Pandemic Junior than Pandemic Light. It wasn't just that we won when I played this with Pandemic vets; we won by a mile. There was never any tension, and about a quarter of the turns we just kind of sat there using one or two actions. It's possible that we just had a really optimal setup and card draws, but given that one of the three players started with one of each type of treasure card and both of the flame tiles had flood cards revealed early, I doubt that. I think the problem is that you don't really care about at least half of the island, so the sense of urgency you get in Pandemic with the outbreaks isn't really there.

Even so, the system isn't terrible, and if I was looking for a co-op game to play with kids, this would be high on my list.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Too easy to my liking.

RATING: 7
2 - [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/4p/user/Vroenis]4 players[/url].
Teaching: 45 - 60 minutes.
Mastery: 30 - 45 minutes.
Another bloody tin, medium box.

Co-op.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/set_collection/user/Vroenis]Set collection[/url], action coordination.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/tag/modular_board/user/Vroenis]Modular board[/url].
Reductionist Pandemic but easier to teach, shorter to complete.
Medium weight, medium-high crunch.
Medium player interaction, mostly verbal.
Medium theme application.

The original reductionist Pandemic by the same designer, Matt Leacock. I really like it as it's a shorter, slightly easier to track iteration of the same dynamic with the tactile fun of flipping and removing tiles and handling artifacts.

Co-op games are intended to be difficult to make victories rare and rewarding, and players need to find the fun in losing (see: Space Alert!). I love chaos, crunch and pressure and while Island probably isn't as chaotic as other games (even Pandemic has the outbreaks that ripple across the board), it can still be punishing. Definitely a good one to introduce folks to co-op gaming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A quick playing co-op with a variable map and multiple player roles.  Simple rules, but challenging to play.  Like many co-ops, there is a great deal of tension trying to collectively surmount the challenge(s).  I have enjoyed my initial plays, but I wonder about how long it can sustain player interest due to it's streamlined design.  Nevertheless, a nice design that offers a good challenge.

RATING: 8
[i]Forbidden Island[/i] is a fun, charming game appropriate for the family magazine editors that turn up their collective noses at [i]Pandemic[/i] whenever I try to suggest that game as an innovative mainstream design that’s also family friendly. [i]Forbidden Island[/i] strips away all the dying and plague – although players are still grave-robbers, mind you – replacing that negativity with colorful components, easy-to-shuffle cards, and chunky tiles, all packaged in an inviting way for game-players everywhere. 

Visit BoardgameNews.com for my [url=http://www.boardgamenews.com/index.php/boardgamenews/comments/game_review_forbidden_island/]complete review[/url] of the game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So I guess I'm a heretic--I consider myself a "gamer" and I like Forbidden Island better than Pandemic.  Here are the reasons:

1. None of that convoluted deck preparation business.  If I didn't have to do it every single time for our Pandemic games, this might be less of an issue.  But I do.  I didn't realize how much of my undesire to play Pandemic was wound up in preparing the stupid deck until I played Forbidden Island.  Maybe I'm just a weenie.

2. Variable board.  I really like this.  The game is different every time.  The connections between "nodes" (tiles) are more uniform than Pandemic's (cities), which implies that they would be less interesting, but I don't find them so.

3. Simpler card exchanging rules.  Exchanging cards in Pandemic without a special power is a pain.  Yes, this adds to the strategy, since you really have to plan well.  But I just find it annoying and unthematic that I can't always give a card to someone when I'm in the same city as them.

4. No hidden cards rules.  You just put 'em face up.  Simple and easy.  Got someone who takes control of every game because they can see every card?  Don't play with them.

5. More appealing ending condition.  Get the treasure and get off the island.  Easy peasy.  In Pandemic, every new player wants to know why we don't have to cure all the diseases.  "Well, because now it's really easy to do so because we've got all the cures!" I say.  Well, why don't we [i]do it[/i] then?!

The theme is more unique in Pandemic, and the outbreak mechanic is cooler than flooding and sinking.  But everything is just simpler, faster, and more straightforward about Forbidden Island.  I groan (inside) when someone wants to play Pandemic, but right now I'll happily play Forbidden Island any time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Forbidden island is a great game.  granted it is pretty easy, and doesn't create a drastic challenge like it's big brother Pandemic, but I feel like it is a game that more non-gamers would be drawn to because of the theme, and complexity.  Also, being a teacher, Forbidden island is a lot easier to pull out with my younger students.  The biggest draw back is I feel it is a lot easier to suffer from an alpha gamer in this game rather than other co-op games.

RATING: 6.742
Very simple cooperative game.  Tiles will flip once when becoming 'flooded' after which you have to 'shore them up' by flipping them back, if you don't then those tiles will start to 'sink' (be removed from the game).  It creates a thematic sense of urgency as the island sinks around you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
For those unsure whether they should spend the green, there's no need to own this if you're an adult who only plays games with adults.  Pandemic is the preferred game, always, under those circumstances.  If you're a gamer with young kids or plastic-hungry pets - as many of us are - then Forbidden Island is a fluffy alternative where tile flipping (shoring up) seems to be a favorite pastime.

The 10-up age suggestion is a bit overboard. An older child would have a good chance of winning with a 7-year-old, a 2-year-old, and a pet rock - because everyone plays with their hand cards revealed.  So if someone wants to call all the plays, they can.

That's to be avoided, of course.  Collaborative conversation is where it's at.

Also, with a few plays under their belt, there's a good chance that a group of kids would be able to play this one entirely unsupervised - something that would never happen with Pandemic due to its awkward set-up.  I'm all about providing the younger set with quality coop alternatives, and Forbidden Island fills that niche in spades.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Nice new Co-op game. Very similar to Pandemic.

RATING: 7.5
Very nice, fast and clean cooperative game. Great for family play. I slightly prefer this over "Pandemic," the earlier game that it is based on. I like the shrinking island feeling here and the claustrophobia that it brings on, and the simplifications to the rules make it play faster without losing the tension and strategy.

RATING: 7
Matt Leacock's simplest co-op game so far.

It has the same mechanics from Pandemic but in a smaller scale. Victory Conditions are also simpler, which makes this game a great way to introduce non-board gamers to the co-op gender.

However, it does not replace Pandemic as a co-op game. If you have to choose between one or another, go with Pandemic. 

Still so, I consider this the best gateway game I have.

RATING: 8
This is a difficult game to beat!

I played this game multiple times the first session and nearly won once, but had fun losing all the same.

The game play is one of those which makes you hope you do not get an ulcer from the constant stress it elicits.  It gets pretty intense and definitely keeps you on your toes!

The components are superb!  The inclusion of actual treasure figures takes the game over the top and makes for a more visually appealing experience.  

The game tiles have beautiful depictions of island locations which contribute nicely to the overall theme of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After a few games this has been a real surprise. I bought it for my son for Christmas as he's not that into confrontational games and thought a co-op would work well. I couldn't of been any more right. It worked a treat. Such a simple game but so difficult to win and a fantastic sense of tension and a relentless fight against the inevitable sinking of the island. 

Fantastic family game for all ages.

RATING: 8
A lighter version of Pandemic, with gorgeous luscious artwork, and great quality components.

One minor gripe is the omission of a standee for the Water Level Marker, but I [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/997946/forbidden-island]made my own[/url] to combat this.

The best diminishing area game I've ever played bar none.

RATING: 7.5
If you are looking for a great stand-alone co-op game I would highly recommend Pandemic, but if you're looking for co-op game to play with younger kids or just a filler game that has more depth than most filler games and captures the essence of larger co-ops Forbidden Island is the way to go.
